text: Cant believe I didnt enter this earlier, at Fizz, way back, maybe while waiting for the Great Lakes beer pairing thing. Yummy, malty, boozey, dried fruit! Serving: Bottle
Bottle share at Evernote in Redwood City, CA. Aroma is sweet malts, caramel, raisins. Taste is creamy caramel with a nice refreshing brightness. Excellent.
Pours a light copper color with a minor sweet malt aroma. Taste is mild caramel with a clean malt flavor. Aftertaste is dry, with minor aluminum film left on the palate.
Recommended to me at the liquor store...happy I took the challenge! Power punch of flavor! Beautiful color. Great autumn brew
October 17, 2015 - sample via bottle at Barrels and Bacon. Clear orange pour. Aroma and taste of sweet malt, fruit and spice.
Bottle. Clear amber orange color with an small head. Malty bread dough aroma with a caramel, toffee and some bourbon flavorings. It is big beer and very good.

bright orange brown pour some cream top. Aroma ozone, caramel, boubon glazed bananas. Tastes big malt but also has light tingly carb and bitter hop balance. Also tried a bottle from 2013. It aged to be overly sweet and malty. Drink this one fresh and enjoy a doppelbock about as good as you can get.

Without a doubt, my favorite beer of all time. Its hard to get, as Capital only offers it around August and September of each year. Fortunately, Im only about 50 miles away from the brewery, so I can usually find it during that period. I love beers that set the mood for the season. This one certainly does that. Im not sure what it is, but sitting around a campfire with a few of these as the leaves are starting to fall in autumn is what life is all about. Its a big beer. If you plan on drinking quite a few of them, make sure you have a "designated carrier" that can drag you into the tent or camper at the end of the session. And try not to fall into the campfire.
Draft at oasis. From notes. Caramel and toffee dominate, hints of Roasty mAlt in the finish.

12 ounce bottle into tulip glass, 2012 vintage bottling. Pours slightly hazy deep reddish copper color with a 2 finger dense light khaki head with great retention, that reduces to a nice cap that lingers. Spotty soapy lacing clings on the glass, with a fair amount of streaming carbonation. Aromas of huge caramel, toast, toffee, biscuit, raisin, plum, fig, date, brown sugar, light nuttiness, light chocolate, slight tobacco/leather and yeast/toasted earthiness. Damn nice aromas with good balance and complexity of dark fruit and dark/bready malt sweetness; with great strength. Taste of big caramel, toast, toffee, biscuit, raisin, plum, fig, date, brown sugar, light nuttiness, light chocolate, slight leather/tobacco, and yeast/toasted earthiness. Slight earthy/roast bitterness on the finish; with lingering notes of caramel, toast, toffee, biscuit, raisin, plum, fig, date, brown sugar, light nuttiness/chocolate, and yeast/toasted earthiness on the finish for a while. Incredible complexity and robustness of big dark fruit and dark/bready malt flavors; with a great malt/dark fruit balance and zero cloying sweetness after the finish. Light-medium carbonation and medium-full bodied; with a very smooth, moderately creamy, and slightly slick/bready mouthfeel that is great. Alcohol is well hidden with only a slight warming present after the finish. Overall this is an awesome doppelbock style. All around great complexity, robustness, and balance of big dark fruit and dark/bready malt flavors; and very smooth to sip on for the ABV. A highly enjoyable offering.

12 oz bottle, poured into a bell glass at approximately 40 degrees F.

A: Pours a honey-gold that is not unlike the color of fresh synthetic motor oil, and settles into the glass as a beautifully clear light amber. I half expected to see some sort of mosquito trapped within the beer, waiting to for us to unlock the genetic secrets of the velociraptor from within it. It formed a decently thick head of perhaps a finger and a half, which quickly died away in a rush of fizzy sounds to leave only a slight white ring around the edges of the glass. No lacing was left to speak of. Bubbles rise steadily from the bottom of the glass the entire time it sits in said glass.

S: Sweet and yeasty, the nose is not unlike glazed bread, reminiscent of some sort of honeyed doughnut. Theres some hints of cherry and I daresay banana faintly in the nose as well.

T: Definitely a sweet beer, with caramel and honey bun flavors striking right out of the gate. A yeastiness makes itself known as the beer moves across the tongue, and the sweetness fades a little to let some cherry and cinnamon in along the sides. This beer finishes with a burst of cherry and raisin, and some faint hints of wood, beneath the last of the honey bun sweetness.

M: Smooth and creamy, this beer drinks like a runny syrup, clinging to the teeth and tongue well after the swallow. Its almost full enough to warrant a "chewy" descriptor, but not quite.

O: As a raging malt addict, I am a fan of this beer. The blend of doppelbock and Oktoberfest works well to create a full-flavored, complex profile that is refreshingly devoid of any noticeable hop presence. I see myself picking this up annually during trips to Chitown, and enjoying it every time.
This beer seems to vary a little year by year, but hit the spot this time around!

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2014 12 oz bottle poured into an imperial pint glass. The aroma is initially play-doh like, followed by some cookie dough qualities. After this, a strong jolly rancher note comes through with secondary notes of caramel, vanilla beans, peanuts, and cooked sugar. It pours an effervescent, clear oily orange-yellow (a bit more on the orange side than yellow) with an off-white, dense and creamy head. The head reduces down to a thin ring, with a silky and filmy surface that eventually becomes oily, and it leaves behind an above average amount of dense, snowdrift lace. The taste is a medium bitter and sweet, leaning a bit towards the bitter side. The medium-full malt bodied beer has a creamy texture with a light, soda-like carbonation. Toasted nuts and caramel are the initial flavors picked up, with a slightly burnt or overly-roasted quality. It finishes a touch dry, but clean, with pine, spice, and bread crust and it leaves behind a roasted nut and slight bitter citrus (lime and grapefruit) aftertaste.
Aroma of light carmal and vanilla. Nice rose copper color with pink head. Taste is bitter and dark. With a lingering after taste. Dark malts. Palate is flat and sticky. Not a fan of this
Bottle. Pours clear copper/brown. Nice head that dissipates quickly. Nose is caramel and brown sugar. Taste adds some nuttiness. A nice dopplebock.
Fantastic caramel notes at the start. Warm and nutty going down. Doesnt drink like an 8% beer. Very smooth and great for the fall season. Would go great with food.
Fantastic beer in the Oktoberfest style, but more. The nose is sweet, with some spice. Lots of caramel malt, toffee and some spice on the palate. An intriguing beer.

20-Feb-14 (12-oz bottle)This beer pours a hazy, medium-brown body with a thin, light-tan head that dissipates quickly. The nose is sweet and caramely with dried fruits, some tropical, almost banana-like fruitiness, and brown sugar, but it lacks the classic toasty, melanoidin character of German examples. Its sweet, very malty, and caramely on the palate, a lot more emphasis on the sugary and malty side with less fruitiness than the aroma shows, but again, whats missing is that German melanoidin character that domestic Doppelbocks just cant seem to nail. Its medium-plus in weight, sweet but not to the point of being cloying, light-medium in carbonation, and pretty smooth on the palate. Overall, this is a fine domestic Doppelbock, deliciously malty, but falls short of excellence when compared to its German counterparts.

Pours a hazy red/orange with slight tan head. Aroma is very full of spice and sweet slightly boozy notes. Taste is slightly sweet with a warming long lasting aftertaste. A great beer for the fall or some good football

No bottling information.
Appearance: The body is crystal clear with an amber to copper hue, accompanied by a dense light tan head that sticks around for a bit.
Aroma: The aroma is how I like my doppelbocks, mildly fruity with big malts. I get a lot of sticky caramel and brown sugar with a fig fruitiness. The aroma is sweet and pleasant with good strength.
Taste: The flavor matches the aroma. The intro is big sweet malts that run through, becoming bigger by the finish. The finish becomes a blend of raisins and caramel, very enjoyable. The finish is quick though leaving a raisin and caramel afterthought.
Palate: Full-bodied, a sticky feel to it, with mild carbonation.
Overall: This is a good doppelbock, I have no complaints about it. The only reason Im not enamored with this is that I feel Troegenator is ultimately a better beer.

Tap at RusTeak. Big amber caramel pour. Big malty sweet aroma with a hint of cherry. Big malt body, little hop bite with slight hint of cherry and warm bread. Big beer, but booze is hidden well. Good brew. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Capital Autumnal Fire I had seems to be different from the one that everyone else had. I dont really get the excitement. The bottle on mine says 7.8% ABV, so maybe this one is different. Decent head on the amber pour, but not a lot of body. Aroma is fresh and malty. Taste is a generic malt with caramel notes and not a lot of hop character. Sugary aftertaste hangs on the palate. Autumnal Fire is ok but certainly not due the hype.
Ruby red pour--very interesting color for the style; off-white head. Nose is caramel, toffee, sweet malts. Taste is sweet sugary bready malts, brown sugar. Thin-medium mouthfeel.

10/17/13 trade from Jamil. What a great Doppelbock! Sweet malt, taffy and brown sugar scent. Dark bronze pour with a medium smooth feel. Sweet malt up front, rich and nutty, brown sugar and taffy finish with a hint of alcohol, but mostly all a great rich flavor. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle--I'm liking the doublebocks. Amber color, the best definition of an amber color I say, brew with no head and like carbonation. Malty aroma with some caramel. Taste is malt, without roast and caramel. The finish is syrupy and sticky. No trace of alcohol. Wish I had a cellar! Total wine. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Beautiful, auburn colored body was clear, and the beer displayed little carbonation, and formed no head. The smell was a mixture of sour dark skinned fruits, caramel, cocoa and coffee. The taste was very fruity, brimming with flavors of cherries, and fig, as well as showing off some vanilla, toffee, and just a hint of chocolate. The body was thicker than medium dense, with sticky initial feel, and a dry finish. I believe this is the first beer from this brewery Ive sampled. It probably wont be the last, based on the quality of this one.
This is my favorite beer, period. No one can beat Capital Breweries Dopplebocks. My only complaint is that I cant get this in California!!!! But I did ship 4 cases with me when I moved!!!
Truly Unique. It is not for everyone but if you have the palate for it, it is amazing.

2009 Bottle from Archer Liquors, Chicago. Pours a muddy brown colorwith no visible head. Nose is mostly burnt malt with caramel. Taste is malty and buttery. Taste is fruity as well, with a long finish. Descentbut nothing special. 
Quaff score 6 / 10

Aged 3 years. Pours a muddy brown with a beige head and aroma of caramel and malt. Taste is of caramel, sweet malt, and light fruits with a malty finish. Very drinkable, alcohol is well hidden, solid doppelbock

Bottle from Breeze Thru cellar aged over 3 years. Pours a coppery brown with almost no head. Rotation builds up a quickly disappearing off-white one that leaves no lacing. Aroma has super sweet caramel, rich grapes, peat and some fruit. Taste is of sweet caramel malt, bread, and sweet and tart fruits. Medium bodied. Finishes sweetly and a bit tart with some yeastiness. Nice solid dopple. Would expect the aging hurt it a bit; oversweetening it.

Capital Autumnal Fire, aged 3 years 7 months in my beer cellar, 7.8% ABV
A 12oz bottle and poured into a Capital Brewery Snifter.
Appearance: Poured ruby brown with a very little head and lacing.
Smell:  Toasted malt and caramel notes, no pronounced hop presence, no obvious off flavors.
Taste:  Dried fruit and cognac sweetness.  A molasses finish lingers.  There is also a slight aftertaste of old leather, but not unpleasant.
Mouth feel:  Medium body and low carbonation, coating the back of the tongue and upper palette with black licorice.  Also a nice warming alcohol finish.
Overall: Capital was the first American craft breweries to combine the Oktoberfest and Doppelbock styles into one amazingly drinkable strong beer.  The cellar aging has brought forward the more bitter flavors to balance with strong sweetness of the young beer.  This is a great cognac-like after diner beverage to enjoy by an open fire with a maduro leaf cigar.

12 oz. bottle. Hazy copper pour, with a small, khaki head. Lots of vanilla, whiskey, butterscotch, with some notes of black bread, pine, and syrup. Very sweet, with a little hop bitterness toward the finish. Heavy body, warm and lively, with a little astringency and stickiness. Overall, this is a thick and sticky beer. Not bad.

Muddy Dark Red, Tan Head, Lots Of Lacing. Sweet Caramel, Creamy Malt, Light Bitter. Very Smooth and Easy To Drink Long Lasting Creamy Sweet Aftertaste and nice tummy warming feeling. Niiiiice. Recommended. New Favorite, will be looking out for it in Autumn.

Bottle.  Pours a clear golden amber color with a small head that quickly fades.  Pretty nice aroma of caramel, cherries, raisins, and bread.  Drinks really smooth.  Easy to drink and a bit boozy at the same time.  Lots of caramel and fruit.  Finish is crisp and smooth, cherry taste lingers.  Medium body, a little syrupy.  Very enjoyable doppelbock.
Excellent to me,. Nice malty taste and almost alike a Barley Wine in strenght. NIce amber touches.
a nice beer with a nutty taste, that this the standard of of good dopplebock. the malts are strong with little hops. the look is clear and not that carbonated, but its very tasty.

Pours a ruby red with a small head that quickly dissipates. Taste is alcohol, molasses and raisins/fruit. Pretty boozy but I keep going back for more. I have a love/hate relationship with this beer. 


---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

12 oz bottle pours a clear copper brown with lots of rising bubbles, small off-white head.  Aroma is full of carmel malts and bread, with some fruit (cherries, raisins, dates).  Body is medium to full with just the right carbonation for the style.  Taste is sweet with a boozy, slightly chemical aftertaste.  A very good doppelbock anyway.  Id love to find this one on tap somewhere.

The aroma is rather non-descript with a hint of caramel malt. The appearance is amber with a small head that fades to nothing. The taste is very smooth with lots of sweet, bread like malt and a touch of fruity yeast. The palate is smooth. Overall a good beer.

I realize this is a pretty decent doppelbock, but the problems I have with the style (overly sweet, chemically caramel flavor) is in this beer as well.  I can appreciate the palate and its rich syrupy character. Josh brought this one back for me from Madison.

Three tries. On tap draft, out of the tank at the brewery, and bottled. Loses a lot in the translation to bottle, IMO. Draft and from the tank - outstanding. Reddish/gold color, a little thick and heavy but good for a cool fall day. Definite toasted malt, grainy, caramel/toffee. Seemed to me it lost the caramel/toffee notes. Capital brews outside Madison,but tankers to Stephens Point for bottling, and the warehouse was really warm - thinkin that isnt good.

Deep amber color. Aroma is sugary and malt. Taste is sort of fruity with a good malt background. Some alcohol burn that is very intriguing. Sticky mouth feel. This is a very good beer. A true autumn beverage.
Clear red pour with a full caramel taste.  Thick mouth.  Aroma of sugar and caramel.  Very easy drinking and full of warm alcohol notes.

Im always glad when I find a new Capital - its not a brewery that I really seek out, the beers are good though.  Clear, dark bronze beer, US longneck bottle with a (ahem) twistoff cap which is really the only thing that spoils the appearance.  Good label.  Canned corn and tannic malt aroma.  Sweet, tangy, lots of fruit (cherry, dates), leather,  a little chewing tobacco.  Medium-heavy mouth, light astringency, raisiny aftertaste with a boozy break.  Quality rendition of the style, and it *is* an epitomical autumn brew.  Alas, I only purchased a single to sample.  ABC, Bull Run.

Crisp, strong aroma has a malty core with an underpinning of honey, cinnamon and cloves. Pours a clear, dark copper, almost mahogany, with a fairly thick light wheat head. Malty flavor has firm earthy, caramel, and honey tones with just hints of spice and wood. Texture has decent body and fizz, leaving an earthy, slightly woody finish and a persistent tingle. Happy Autumn!

Tallahassee, Fl - New Leaf Market - 12 oz bottle. Sparkling dark copper pour, light bubbly off-white head. Sweet aroma of molasses and raisins. Flavor has the same sweetness with some solid date notes, some prunes, a dash of molasses. Mouthfeel is thick and rich. Make a good winter bellywarmer.
A rich doppelbock perfect on the nose and above average on the rest. A golden honey color tinged with tan, this one is as refreshing as it is complex. Who doesnt love a great fall beer?

Pours a slightly hazy medium dark amber with scant head and lace.  The payoff is in the taste - sweet toasted caramel malt and light fruit leavened with mild bittering through the finish.  The balance is exquisite and the taste is a chorus of malty grains and caramel toffee sweetness.  Highly recommended.

Bottle shared by ygtbsm94. Thanks Brad.

The beer is dark orange to brown in color, appearing hazy and sporting a thick, creamy off-white head. The aroma offers toffee, malt, bread, butterscotch, some sweet fruits. Really nice and easy drinking. Exceptionally smooth feel. Very light in body and creamy on the palate. I would definitely have this again.

Dark hazy orange in appearance. This features a very rich caramel, malty, chocolate, and yeasty flavor base. Feels quite crisp on the palate despite the carbonation. All and all, one of the best tasting doppelbock-style beers I have had yet!
12 ounce bottle.  Pours a clear copper with a small white head.  Aroma of malt, brown sugar, dark fruit, and grain.  Taste is sweet caramel malt, toffee, dark fruit, citrus, and a bit of hops.  Nice!

Originally reviewed: 11/10/10. Awesome bottle received from BeerFMAndy (BA)  in a surprise box that showed up at my door one day! Should I say KarmaFMAndy??

12oz bottle poured into a giant mug. Pours a dark copper color with a thick creamy off-white head on top. No lace sticks around at all. Nose is full of caramel notes, toffee, candied sugar, lightly toasted. 

The mouth is full and brimming with depth. My experience with this style has yielded surprisingly thin feels on most. This one is full and hefty, what I would expect from a "double" bock. This is a malt-bomb for sure! Tons of sweet toffee, caramel, faint banana, light booziness that complements well. The alcohol adds just enough to the flavor, without making it overbearing in any way. Wonderfully executed. This is a stellar beer and one of the best of the style. Recommend. You are the man, Andy.

Amazing beer that I wish could be served all year long.  This dopplebock has such a nice caramel and malty taste with many different flavors that excite the pallet.  Very much a sipping on the couch after dinner beer.

Courtesy of Rando7.  Pours a amber/red/gold color, a little light for the style, between a dopplebock and heller bock.  The aroma is caramel, brown sugar, light fruit.  The flavor is sweet, caramel, a little more bread like.  Medium in body.  The finish is sweet, fruity, light noble hop bittering.  Weird for a dopplebock.  In appearance, flavor and body it is more like a blend of a heller bock and dopplebock.  The description says it is based on an "Oktoberfest personality", and it does bear some resemblance to the Marzen style as well.  Still, a very drinkable beer.  Definitely glad I got the chance to try it.  Thanks, Randy.

Pours a medium amber with a light head.  Aroma consists of orange and banana with some caramel notes.  Lively flavor or caramel and sugar.  It is sweet and smooth, with the heavier alcohol not very noticeable.  Enjoyable.

Bottle pours orange/amber with an off-white head. Aroma is malt driven with notes of caramel, toast, and earth. Flavor is sweet with additional notes of dried fruit. Overall body is moderate to full with a rich, boozy finish.

Big thanks to Adam for this 12oz bottle.

Pours a deep clear copper with a small beige head that leaves a soapy cap on top.

Aroma is toasted caramel malts, toffee and light fruits.  Theres a bit of cinammon apple character to the nose that certainly stands out vs. some others in the style.

Taste is even sweeter with brown sugar, toffee and overripe fruits up front.  The backbone is all caramel malts and toasted bread.  The finish is dry and crisp with more sweetness than I was expecting.

The mouthfeel is creamy and smooth with strong carbonation.

This is an excellent doppelbock and maybe just one step behind the best in the style, but its not far back.  Sugar, fruit, bread all wrapped into one beer.

Tap pour after having this multiple times in bottle form.  Aroma is sweet and boozy.  Nice appearance that matches the namesake properly.  Flavor is almost identical to the aroma - very sweet, and drinks stronger than the 8.5% it is listed at.  Solid beer that Ill almost surely enjoy again!

12 oz bottle.  Clear topaz with a balsa head, some lace.  Nose is blackberry preserves, orange peel and candi.  Chewy medium body with a lively buzz.  Taste is caramel, maple and allspice finishing slightly bitter with burnt sugar.  Quite sweet but maintains enough balance to have a few.

Pours a hazy dark burnt orange with small offwhite head that disappates quickly. The aroma is rich and malty with caramel foremost, some breadiness-earthiness. The flavor is smooth, deep malt with raisin and toffee character and dark toast. There are just a touch of herbal hops..licorice?  The finish is a little bit boozy and leaves a sticky aftertaste.
It is great by American Standards, and a bit lacking by German standards but a solid doppelbock.
Bottle into a pint glass.  I picked up on a caramel and butterscotch taste, sort of like a Werthers candy.  Its a nice dessert beer, something to have after a meal.

12 oz bottle. Pours a hazy dark burnt orange with small offwhite head. The aroma is rich and malty with raisin and toffee foremost, some toast, some wet leaves, some sweet earthiness. The flavor is smooth, deep malt with raisin and toffee character and dark toast. There are some vanilla and cracker notes, maybe just a touch of herbal hops. The finish is a little bit woody and leaves a sticky aftertaste.
Gabf. Fairly clear, golden yellow orange appearance with an off white head. Very rich, sweet, caramel, toffee malty aroma. Very sweet, rich caramel, licorice, lager flavor but quite rich.

bottle in a pint glass (BOTTLE SAYS 7.8%, NOT 8.5% - I FEEL CHEATED) - Pours amber with rich off-white foam and lacing.  Nose is caramel malts.  Aroma is alcohol, caramel malts, hops and, pumpkin(?).  Taste starts off sweet but ends on a dry and bitter note.  Medium to long finish with almost a sour end.  Definitely an introspective beer: I love it.

1. Look - A clear amber colored German style lager with a nice head.
2. Sniff  There is a big malty aroma and a hint of alcohol.  
3. Sip  This is a medium bodied lager with a metallic taste and a soft bitter finish.  
4. Another Look  This lager looks like a much stronger and heavier ale but it is quite the opposite.
5. Evaluate - Overall, this is a quality beer that has an initial sweet malty flavor with a dry metallic finish and loaded with alcohol.  Give it a try and eat with a bratwurst.

35cl bottle from a friend.
Thick creamy white head.  Clear amber pour.  Very nice.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2011 Very good maltiness in the aroma without being cloying.  The flavor is malty and slightly grainy.  Very reminiscent of a German dopplebock, a little leaner in body but still a great beer.
Oozing machismo.  Full of rich sweet caramel flavor without ever verging into the domain of cloying.  Remarkably drinkable for 8.5%.
Big caramel and slightly roasted malts. Drinks smooth and clean, but also deserves to be savored
Yum!  Such great flavor and aroma in this beer.  Need to track down some more!

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2011 All of the above but I found it  sticky in the throat...producing phlem, etc...Not very drinkable unless you are eating something to clean the palate. Overall nice taste, this is my favorite Capital Doppel Bock so far. No weird cider off taste. Not much of an alcohol burn. 

Revisited: Oct 24th, I must have had an old bottle back in July. This is much better. Beautiful red/orange amber, Smell caramel, toffee, coffee. Taste caramel toffee dried fruit...prune/apricot, late citrus hop, a good alcohol burn.  Med carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2011 Bottle.  Aroma is sweet malts with notes of carame, roasted malts, and a tiny bit of dark fruit.  Palate is thick, but much lighter than the aroma lets on.  Taste is sweet finishing dry.

12 ounce bottle.  Served in a mug, the beer pours a slightly hazy reddish/amber color with about a half inch off-white head that went away quickly.  There isnt much lacing left on the glass at all.  Aroma is toasted malt, brown sugar, toffee and a bit of dark fruit.  Taste is pretty much just like the aroma, but theres some butterscotch noticable too.  Its a good, malty brew.  Mouthfeel/body is medium, its a bit creamy with low/moderate carbonation.  I think its a decent brew.  Its not my favorite doppelbock but Id try this one again in the future, its definitely worth a try.

Color was a dark amber, head was fair and light.  Ended bubbly.  

Dark fruits, fruit esters, rich malts on the aroma.  

More malty and rich taste, sweet, nutty, tinge of heat.  

Clean finish, maybe a hint of malty linger.  Slick feel, medium body.  

Overall, damn decent DBock.
bottle bonused by jameskennedy, thanks! clean and balanced, easy drinking doppel, nice offering for a year round. enjoyable beer.

12 oz. bottle from The Party Source. Pours a clear copper color with a small white head. Aroma of sweet caramel malts, wet grains, buttered toast, and brown sugar. Flavor of sweet caramel malts, brown sugar, syrup, soggy cereal, and butterscotch. Medium-bodied, with moderate carbonation and a sticky, malty mouthfeel. Nice sipping doppelbock but the aroma seems just a little off.
Not much of a scent, red amber color with a strange taste that I cant quite put my finger on.

Source: 12 oz bottle from local retailer.

Aroma: Its got that smell which seems to be held in common amongst lagers; its not a very strong smell and, to tell the truth, its kind of hard to define.

Appearance: The pour is clear and moderately deep amber. The head on top of the pour is a very thin off white color.

Taste: Similar to the smell comments that Ive made, theres that lingering taste which runs across many lager styles (which is hard for me to define). The malty flavors are strong in this one, with just a tiny amount of hoppy bite. Its got a bit of a flush of sweetness (not too strong, mind you) on the aftertaste, which is nice.

Palate: Very smooth on the palate with a moderate to moderatly thick body to it. Theres also a noticeable amount of carbonation going on here.

Overall: For some reason, I want to describe this beer with the word "warm". A thick and hearty doppelbock which I wont mind going after again.

bottle,. thanks to a trade with pawola22, red orange color with creamy off white foam, aroma is butterscotch, waffle batter, candied sugar, flavor of sweet malty pancakes and raisin nut bread, sweet toffee ice cream finish
The aroma is so fascinating. Red licorice. The color is a bright orange-red. Beautifully balanced dopplebock.... A little anticlimax in the taste. But still nice.

This one poured a very dark brown with a very thin head that dissipated quickly.  It had sweet caramel malt as expected from a dopplebock, almost with a hint of coffee.  The hops were sprucelike with a touch of grain (maybe the yeast).  A very good dopplebock, just as expected.  Nothing more or less.
user_location: Lake in the Hills, Illinois, USA

text: from a sampler / singleton from Sonoma in Delavan.  Amber color; thin head; mild taste....a good but not great double bock...

From a 12oz Bottle.  Pours a transparent, ruddy copper colored body with a thin finger of off-white foam.  Malty, melanoidin rich aroma of raisins and toast.  Honey and grape.  Mild alcohol warmth, clean, and no hops noted.  Medium bodied, moderately carbonated mouthfeel with a chewy malt texture.  Rich malt flavors of toast, raisin, and light leather.  Light herbal hop bitterness in the finish, along with a moderate alcohol warmth that also adds some bitterness perception to balance the malt sweetness.  Rich malt sweetness, but well attenuated, ensuring adequate drinkability.  The commercial description of a beefed up oktoberfest is accurate, but conceptually doesnt work as well as blond doppelbocks or traditional darker doppelbocks for my palate.  I dont find the flavors to be any more complex than an oktoberfest, but the drinkability is decreased.  Regardless, its still a well made beer with an impressive malt flavor.

Big thanks to chewy08rx for sending this one out my way.

A: Pours a slightly-murky deep, creamy gold with a nice white head. Minimal lacing as it went down.

S: Sweet caramel malt with a bit of butterscotch and toffee.

T: Caramel, bready malt, butterscotch, toffee, and slight hints of alcohol; a nice richness altogether.

M: Creamy and smooth. Goes down way easy for a doppelbock.

D: Very nice. I love the take on the style.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 04-17-2010

12oz bottle pours a translucent but really bright, blazing ruby amber with a creamy, frothy off white head.  Aromas of fruit, apples, pears, malty, a little boozy, dried leaves.  Flavor is sweet, fruity, pears, caramel, whole grain bread, a little banana, some rum, some raisin, a touch medicinal.  Full bodied, lightly sticky finish.
12oz bottle thanks to MattS-NJBeerCo-pours a light tan head and copper color.  Aroma is sweet medium malt-caramel, some spice/herbal hops.  Taste is sweet medium malt-caramel secondary spice hops.

Pour a nice dark red amber with a medium head with a slow fade.  Aroma was nice and was slightly sweet with malts predominating.  Taste with similar with the with slightly sweet malts going in with hint of the high gravity alcohol and it finished with medium hop character.  Palate was good but not outstanding.  Overall, very nice smooth brew that has similarities to malt liquour but with much more character.
user_location: Town of Maple Creek, Wisconsin, USA

text: 12 oz bottle shared with rateyourpoison. Pours a slightly hazy amber brown color with a small creamy off white froth. Aroma is very rich malts, nutty and toasty. Delicious overripe fruit note that is just bursting, so sweet and juicy. Flavor starts with a subdued rich sweet molasses and caramel note, picking up a subtle spice note with a nice honey and smooth grainy backbone. Finishes sweet and refreshing, a bit nutty in the aftertaste. Medium to full body and a surprisingly sharper carbonation. Really good American attempt at a classic German style

12oz btl thanks to FunkyBrewster. Clear copper pour with a light tan head. An aroma of carmel and toffee maltiness. Crisp to start with that sweet carmel malt followed by a bit of hop spice. Nice malt and hop balance. Not too gummy, just the right amount of richness.

Bottle: Pours a Dark Red/Golden, with an off white head. Aroma is one part honey, one part apple peel. Its pretty smooth tasting, with modest carbonation. Very Sweet brew; Caramel Malt, Light Hops, Honey, Brown Sugar, and something slightly bitter that I cant put my finger on. Its better than I expected, frankly - but honestly, I just drank a Celebrator and an Andechser...

Bottle. pour is clear copper color with a creamy off white head. Aroma is brown sugar and malt. Taste is sweet brown sugar and vegetables and some wood. Palate is clean creamy and fizzy and finishes dry. Very enjoyable wish I had more.

12 oz bottle from Archer Liquors. A sweet mess. Dark amber color with an off-white soapy head that thins quickly. Aroma of malts, lots of sugar, molasses and caramel. Tastes of roasted malts, caramel to sweeten the taste.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear copper red with a medium head.  Aroma is bready, some alcohol heat. This one is more complex than i thought it would be.  Some  bread, biscuit, caramel, fruity toffee, and alcohol going on.  Overall I enjoyed it.

bottle - Pours dark amber with a one finger off-white head.  The aroma is of caramel malt with some light fruitiness.  The flavor is sweet caramel malt.  Theres a hint of dark fruit.  Its medium bodied and solid enough, but didnt overly impress me.  Its good, but its no Celebrator.

Bottle...  Poured foggy amber/burgandy with a moderate, white head that faded quickly.  Aroma was a brilliant buttery-toffee with notes of malts and cocoa.  Fruity, juice-like with slight hops, toasted malts and caramel-like tones.

Thanks to Gillard for the share.  Pours slightly hazy red-brown with an off-white head.  Nose is grain, gourd, brown sugar, dark malt, and a bready/ doughy-ness.  Flavor is the same with an uncommon depth for a doppel and a hint of booziness.  Very interesting, would love to try again.

Appearance: Attractive light brown with red folds and a 1 finger slightly off white crown that rapidly dissipates and shows a touch of lace.

Smell: Bold notes of maple syrup, brown sugar, molasses, dark malt, bread and a touch of hops.

Taste: Strong raisin bread note, with a touch of dark malt and a honey smooth finish.

Mouthfeel: Medium bodied and smooth with a good amount of carbonation.

Drinkability: Easy flavors despite the high abv.

This is a pretty nice beer for the fall season. Not one Ill seek out in a trade again, but Im glad I got to try it.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-27-2009

Draft @ Hackneys, Chicago, IL. Pours a dark amber color with a small off-white head. Has a fruity malty caramel aroma. Fruity malty caramel flavor with some spicy hints. Has a fruity malty caramel finish.

Great doppelbock, theres a slightly alcoholic/hoppy almost acidic finish which is lovely. Maybe the best beer from CApital Ive had. Present from my friend Joel (Uckelman rater) who brought it from WI.

Thanks 2 John 4 this .. . Pours a dark orange brown .. has good foam .. if youre here, that means..oh boy! .. . sweet browned fruit aroma .. a tad muddled, with some fruits and honey .. drinkable, but to sweet to be sessionable .. ok stuff .. . wow, she went to college!
Doppelbock not being my favorite style, this is very good nonetheless. Good caramel flavor and some nice maltiness that really makes it a treat to drink.

2008 bottle thanks to beeronmypants.  Thanks, Dennetta!  Pours a pleasant chesnut with a quickly receding head.  Nose of sweet malts, caramel and toffee. Prunes, golden raisins, and other dark fruits.  Full palate.  Nice.

Pours a slightly hazy, copper color with deep red under tones and a tall off white head that quickly fades do a smooth white film. Aroma has a strong fruity note composed of apples and light cherry, a very smooth toasted Munich malt end, light spicy ending with some mild nutty notes as it warms up. Flavor starts with a great toasted malt character up front, moving into a well balanced sweetness derived mostly from the the malt and producing a mild apple and pear fruitiness, lots of esters and finishes with a light almost cinnamon spiciness. Body is very heavy and has a very hefty oiliness from the high amount of sugars present in the brew. Not much lacing is produced and the carbonation present is low and very fine. Overall a solid brew but I find the sweetness a tad bit on the high side.

courtesy of tpd975
pours amber, thin off-white head
aroma-flavor, light dark fruits, caramel malts and roasted flavors. Some hints of bitterness. Nice doughy malty finish mixed with a lingering mild bitterness topepd with some dark fruits.
Pours a clear copper red with a loose beige foam.  Aroma is toasty, bready, some alcohol heat.  Taste is bready, biscuit, caramel, fruity toffee, thin and alcohol.

12 oz. bottle from shigadeyo.  Pours a clear deep amber color with a small ivory head that quickly collapses.  The aroma is malty with caramel being dominant.  There is also a strong fruity component with light hints of yeast.  The flavor is sticky sweet caramel, rich malts, ripe fruit, with a slight amount of roasted nuts. The alcohol remains well hidden except in its warming effect toward the finish. The light bitterness in the finish is a welcome departure from the overall sweetness of the beer. Mouthfeel is   thicker than expected for this medium-full bodied beer which goes down smoothly. I have wanted to try this for some time and was not disappointed.

Deep amber with an off white head and lace. Aroma is light brown sugar lager yeast and a hint of abv. Flavor mirrors aroma with a hint more warmth on the flavor. A bit thin and foamy but overall a pretty nice beer.

One of Wisconsins finest, a gorgeous amber-red ale, with an added stream of CO2 floating to the sky.  A light head, slightly sticking to the side of the glass.  This Beer is all about its taste (and alcohol content).  Fantastic initial rush of fruits, banana and a hint of caramel, although complexity is a bit lacking.  Fantastic.

12oz bottle courtesy of BOLTZ7555  thanks J!  Pours a fiery dark orange with a half finger off-white head that faded fast.  The nose is caramel, pumpkin pie spice, and a light vegetal aroma.  The taste is brown sugar, caramel malt, molasses and some spiked raisins in the finish.  Medium bodied.  Decent, but too sweet for me.  Thanks again Jason!
Reddish brown pour.  Fruity and malty aroma.  Flavor is loaded with dried pears, raisins, malt, toffee and honey.  Not half bad.  Pretty damn good actually.

Had their Blonde, so I had to try this. Pours a dark mahogany with a small head. Smells of dried fruit, nuts, allspice, and like freshly burnt campfire wood. Heavy malt taste, with some caramel and coffee, a bit of fruit notes, and just hint of alcohol. Finishes clean and sweet, barely any bitterness. Nice one.

12 oz bottle purchased at Blue Max in Burnsville, Minnesota. Pour is clear ruby golden with a smallish light tan head. Aroma of big chewy nutty sweet caramel maltiness. Some dark dried fruit (prune?), some mild banana ester - touch of straw rounds it out. Taste is the chewy caramel honey malt sweetness, followed closely behind by straw and finally the mild banana yeastiness and dry bitterness. Decent transitions of flavors, nice melding. Palate is medium, decent carbonation - a bit long with the estery finish. At almost room temperature some alcohol was noticeable. Nice sipper.

UPDATED: SEP 21, 2011 Poured from bottle into beveled mug.

Rich, clear mahogany with a fantastic red glow when held up to the light. Small off-white head, which leaves fine bubbles down the side of the glass.

Aroma of strong cherry, caramel, toast, biscuit and noble hops. Smells like a cross between a Marzen and a standard Bock, with maybe a tad more noticeable alcohol.

A blast of semi-sweet cherry and biscuit malts, with some caramel and other fruit underpinnings. The noble hops provide a touch of spicy, dry counterbalance.

Moderate carbonation, with a creamy, chewy body that isnt as chalky as some Doppelbocks are. A slight warmth serves as a reminder about the alcohol.

Simply a fantastic beer. While this should be a sipping beer, the tendency is to want to drink it like a Marzen. One of the best Doppelbocks out there, even if not truly to style.

Ok, now that I have officially reviewed this, I can now emphatically state that this, Founders Harvest Ale and SurlyFest are my favorite Autumn brews. At least for now; we will see if I can find something to top them next year.

Bottle - Had this one many times over the years, so I figured I would finally rate it. Pours deep amber with a creamy light brown head. It smells sweet, malty, and caramelly, but its a bit cloying and too boozy. Taste is better than it smells, malty but less sweet. Theres some roast and hops on the finish to balance it out. Its smooth and a bit syrupy, and it gets better as it warms. Definitely doesnt knock my socks off like it used to, but its decent.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2009 Caramel Toffee, Maple Syrup. Nice amount of Hops, appley - Bright, excellent level of sweetness (drink it cold, though - warm is a touch too sweet) and great balancing bitterness. Too boozy. Malt flavors are not that interesting (though they are good), hoppiness adds some interest back. Lighter in color and flavor (lighter flavors - not milder) than other dopplebocks Ive had.

orange color, respectable off white head, some lace.  nose of sweet malt, hint of fruitiness.  flavor of sweet malt, but not as sweet as the nose.  there is a touch of earthiness to the taste. medium bodied, light bitterness in the finish.  well hidden alcohol.  i didnt detect the 8.5%  i had a sample of this @ a beer tasting @ family liquors in homewood.

From the bottle, pours a clear deep red with very little head.  Malty aroma.  Tate is thick and malty, caramel is the other dominant flavor.  A little bit of toffee and the slightest hint of alcohol in the aftertaste.  Pretty drinkable, smooth, the better of their two doppelbocks.

Pours a clear dark ruby brown with a soft white head. The aroma is almost like a scotch ale. Earthy bread and peat, with some light spices, toffee, and gingerbread. The flavor is very sweet, toffee, caramel, and a bit of earthy hops with a bitter punch on the finish.

Almost looks like fire! Rich and deep red-purple color with thin layer of foam. Absolutely perfect aroma of toffee-cookie and juicy malts. Flavor is borderline cloying. Toffee malts are in full abundance, with a thick palate. A tingle of hops finishes it off within the realm of balance. Drink fairly cool to ensure that balance.

Draft at the OF.  Deep orange-toffee brown.  Thin head.  Solid deep malt tones, although there is a touch of dirty graininess, as per most Capital beers.  Relatively low CO2, with some crisp, mild bitterness up front.  Caramel, amber, and chocolate nuances.  Smooth caramel finish.  OK.

Bottle from Archer Liquors. Pours a clear reddish copper with a two finger bubbly beige head. Aroma is bigger than caramel. Some spicey notes. Full bodied with creamy carbonation. Flavor is spicey caramel. Mildly fruity. Finishes with a hint of treacle. Pretty good beer.!
Dark brown pour, malty aroma with rye coming through.  Sweet, malty flavor with a caramel finish.
Pours murky brown/orange.  Aroma of fruit and spice. Deep roasted maltiness with hop aftertaste.  Warmth that resides.  Best of both worlds.
Tap, The Map Room, Chicago, IL. Deep ruby colour, spiced pumpkin and malt aroma. Thick tasting with some alcohol burn that fades. Sweet finish with some faint bite.
BOTTLE: clear red/brown pour, small frothy head. Sweet/malt nose, taste is sweet, bread, mild hop, caramel - some creaminess to the body. Excellent stuff!

Bottle. A cloudy deep amber pour with a small but lasting light tan head ,some jagged lacing left , light to medium carbonation. Aroma of brown sugar , toffee,caramel and bread crust . Flavor is a little more complex than expected. Earthy sweet malt, rasins ,cinnamon , and lightly spicy hops , lightly bitter but more sweet than anything . Full body, creamy mouthfeel . a light peppery pine finish . Alcohol is well hidden , so you could drink a couple of these if you like sweet malty brews . A very nice beer and much better than expected .

Tap at the Map Room.  Deep amber pour with a thick white head.  The nose is lightly malty and sweet.  Lots of lingering toffeei/caramel character.  A light earthy hoppiness, but there is a lot more sweetness than they can handle.  There is also a sort of dankness through the middle that I cant really say Im a fan of.  Sort of unclean and mostly unappealing.

Has a clear ruby and dark copper pour with light copper and orange hues, made a quick head of off-white bubbles that disperse to a ring and scattered cover, some effervescence, left a little lacing on the sides of the glass, aromas of bread and caramel sweetness, some fruit fragrances, big malt flavors with bread and caramel sweetness, good mouth feel, not overly sweet as some Dopples but more sweetness than I prefer, wish this was a bit drier, I would have enjoyed this beer more.

This one, this year,  like the oktober-fests, is too sweet. *sigh* big disappointment. Poured with a nice off- white head and lots of lace. Color is a lovely clear copper. Aroma is malty, toffee, and caramel. Flavors about the same, but less toffee and sweeter. Bodys good and carbonation too. A little boozy at the very end. Finish is ok.

12 oz. bottle at Lunar Brewing Co. Poured to a Czech pils glass a clear, copper hue with a light tan, foamy head that diminished quickly and left only spots of lacing which also were short lived. The aroma was smooth malt, brown sugar sweetness, and big caramel notes. The flavor was the same similarly strong notes, with some toastiness and modest hop bitterness to compliment. Somewhat syrupy, medium+ body, and alcohol presense toward the finish. A very good Kirby niche beer.
Had this before it got gold at GABF.  A very solid doppelbock and one of my favorites from Capital.
Poor, pour.  Bad aroma.  Average finish.  This really isnt a very good beer. Try some Ocktoberfest and youll be more satisfied.  Capital Brewery is extremely overrated!!!  Go Bells

Pours a beautiful dark red copper color with  a huge tan head. Nose is mostly malt with some hop notes. Very creamy and smooth on the palate. Sweet taste of malt, molasses and carmel. Very cloying beer that pairs well with nuts and cheese but stands well on its own.

2008 bottle...

pours a clear bright coppery brown capped by a large orange tinted light brown head. 

big ol yeasty nose reminds me of home made raisin bread... yeast, raisins, cinnamon and other warm spices, caramel and malt. 

the flavor is the same... very doughy with a dry nearly bitter finish. nicely balanced with a long finish and aftertaste. 

the medium body is quite creamy and rich yet easy to put away. if it werent 8.5% i would drink it all day. 7/3/7/4/16/3.7
Bottle courtesy of hellbilly.  Pours a clear auburn brown with a nice tan head.  Nutty malt, caramel, fruit and yeast in the aroma and flavor.  Unexpectedly creamy palate.  Very nice.  Thanks Josh!
Bottle with bman1113vr. Red pour with a beige head. Aroma of raisins, yeast, bread, prunes, cinnamon. Taste was primarily bread, caramel and very doughy.

Bottle thanks to pepsican. Pours with a frothy, lightly off-white head over a hazy amber brown body. good lace.  Aroma is caramel, raisins, vinous, plums, toffee, dirt, malty, fresh dough and dark fruits. Taste is raisins, caramel, plums and prunes. Lightly creamy mouthfeel, noticeable alcohol presence.

Thanks to HogTownHarry for this!! Nice clean copper colour with a large off whiate head. Aroma: Bread, malt, winter fruit, slight alcohol and treacle. Flavour: malt, nuts, caramel, quite chewy, hops present in the finish. Pleasant bitter finish.

Pours clear bright copper with a creamy yellow-beige tw finger head that has decent retention. Aroma is tons of toasted malt, raw grain, caramel, date nut bread, an earthy wood note, a hint of molasses. Flavor opens with caramel and toasted malt sweetness, followed by a little nectarine, and some sweet nutty notes. Finish is grainy and a hint of bitterness and straw come in right at the end.

12oz bottle shared by MrFacto at Pre-Sex - thanks, Matt! Id been wanting to try this for a while, and a nice doppel went down well in the midst of all those massive barrel-aged beers. Not a huge body, but certainly hefty and chewy enough. The nose is sweet, malty, toasty, and complex. Its got a rich and lasting flavor, with the toastiness coming even further to the fore as it lingers. Very nice, Ill have to get some more of this.

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2009 12 oz bottle. Pours a redish-orange with almost no head. The aroma is almost non-existent. It has a light body, thin feel, lively carbonation, with a long finish. The after taste seems to have a few stages.

12 ounce bottle courtesy of Alraomon. Thanks again! Pours a 

cranberry color with a thin head. Low head retention and lacing. 

Aroma of toasted malts, bread, fruity notes and caramel. Taste 

is cherry, cotton candy and roasted malts. Medium bodied.

very high rating made me want this one but not the kind of bock I had in mind more like a marzen reminded me of munsterfest pour was amber brown with off white head with aromas of carameliezd malts with the taste of the same sweet finish dont get me wrong it was a very good brew after reading the commercial description it is based on octoberfest very easy drinking so my ? is a marzen closly related to a doppebock both are lagers but is a dopplebock just the next step up the ladder

Crushed with Honkeybra.  What matters most is how well you walk through the fire, aight?  Much malt sweetness on the nose, and a awesome mouthfeel.  Always impressed by doppels with a good hop presence, and that’s why I’m impressed.  Very drinkable.
Crushed with thedude in Galesburg, IL at Budde’s Pizza. This is alright. Amber pour. A bit sweet and some hops. Good mouthfeel, finish is a bit dry. TheDude says 13/20, and I believe him.

Draught at GABF 2008.
Cloudy amber coloured with a medium sized off white head.
Malty aroma of fruits, caramel and hops.
Fruity flavour of malts, caramel and hops.
Hoppy finish.

Bottle from kmeves. Thanks man! Auburn pour with a thin head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel, toffee, and dark fruit. Flavors of toffee, chocolate, and dark fruit. Pretty damn sweet and malty. Smooth with a nice warming effect.

12oz bottle from drewbeerme.  thanks man!.... pours a cloudy reddish brown with a thin light tan head.... aroma caramel malts, light cocoa, dark fruits and generally sweet.... flavors dark fruit (raisins and figs), caramel malt, and bit sugary. mild carbonation and decent mouthfeel.  a good brew for the autumn season.
Pours brown with an off white head.  Aroma of caramel,  spice and alchohol.  Taste is pretty dominated by alchohol and caramel/toffee with some raison.  Not bad.

On tap.  Rich buttery, caramel flavor.  Some alcohol presence, in a good, warm you up, sort of way.  Rather sweet, probably too sweet for some tastes, but a good sipping beer that went well with my Maple Glazed tenderloin.  Hope to have another one.

This one disappointed me. Not much here, more grain and alcohol than maltyness. 
Not very smooth.

Solid amber/brown pour.  Whitish head.  Malty earthy aroma.  Malty, caramel/toffee with some raisin like flavors, some minute sweet spices.  Biscuity.  Caramel apple likeness.  A little light bodied, but not unusual for the style.  Not much hop presence to speak of.  First beer Ive had from Capital and not bad at all.

text: Pours a reddish brown with a tan head. Aroma is of malts, spice, and powerful alcohol. Taste is malts, caramel, and hops. Body is too watery, with a big alcohol presence. Nice lingering sweetness with hints of cinnamon makes up for the watery first.

Medium/dark amber color.  Some caramel and prune in the flavor.  A mild bitter finish.  Small thin head with no lacing.  Alcohol definitely present, a little overpowering for the flavor present.  Celebrator from Ayinger is much much better.  But this is a good attempt from a company from Wisconsin.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2008 Deep copper/amber color with a thin tan head.  Nicely roasted and rich malty flavor with a slightly bitter finish and a light caramel aroma. For those about to bock, FIRE!, we salute you.
[Bottle] Pours a deep copper with a soapy beige head. Aroma is slight, with some caramel in there. Flavor is caramel and raisins with little else.
medium bitterness, light sweetness, medium sourness, nice light reddish color, and a finely balanced malty taste.  Very smooth, and surprisingly light.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a dark reddish amber color, slight head.  Aroma is very rich, with malt notes and spice abounding.  Flavor is similar, very malty, some spicy brown sugar, currants, kind of like a mincemeat pie in a bottle.  Finishes with a heavy alcohol taste.  Palate is thick, which gives it a doughy kind of feel.  It’s decent, but it’s too heavy to be a casual drink.

pours a nice dark amber-copper colour with a light tan head. Aroma is roast malt, caramel,  cherry wood, light herbal hop. 
Flavour is  biscuity malt, a little thin on the palate I thought. Light medicinal alc.-hop bitterness. I wasn’t as impressed with this one as a lot of people apparently are. Not bad though.

Bottle:  Pours a clear ruby/golden with a light creamy golden tan head.  Aroma is sweet malt and caramel with a hint of floral hops.  Has a very malty flavor along with sweet brown sugar, lighter caramel than expected, and a light touch of herbal hops to finish.  A warming sensation takes over while being consumed.  Alcohol is prevalent in the flavor.  Pretty good brew.
Pours a clear amber with white/cream colored head. Aroma is hops/malts, brown sugar. Flavor is caramel and malts with definite toffee notes.  Body is medium with fair carbonation.
rich malty nose, flavor very clean, with nice clean finish, nicely balanced. tastes like a doppelbock

12 oz bottle. Pours deep reddish amber with nice and creamy off-white head. Aroma is hops, caramel, spices and brown sugar. Flavor is spicy with brown sugar, caramel, toffee, cinnamon and hops. Very nicely done and perfect for cool fall evening.  Alcohol is there but not over powering. Nicely done and the best beer I have had from this brewery.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2008 Wow what a fantastic color, pours a deep rich clear glowing red with a small creamy beige head.  Spicy aroma of caramel and cinnamon.  Taste is somewhat dry at first, lots of spicy cinnamon with some faint sweet cherry, brown sugar, fruit and caramel malt.  Not extremely rich for a doppelbock, however the cinnamon flavor is a nice twist and works well.   I dont know about being a brandy snifter beer... its not particularly heavy, drinks easily for a doppelbock.  A bit floral and fruity. Medium/full body, however just heavier water feeling, not sticky at all, very light sizzling carbonation.   Watch out as there is no hint of the 8.5% at all.
NIce deep amber color, rich sweet aroma, the flavor was a little hot with alcohol but other than that I’ve not read any other reviews I disagree with so I’ll keep it short.

UPDATED: MAR 9, 2009 Bottle, dimple mug.  Pours a caramel amber color with a thin beige head.  In the glass, garnet when backlit.   Aromas of raisins, caramel, some alcohol, rather brandy-like.  Flavor comparatively muted.  Dark flavors, caramel, chocolate, very much there.  What could be a nice malt complexity, cider, raisins, fading towards plums, completes for attention with the alcohol and its residual warmth, and the beer suffers for this.  Hint of cardamom at the front, shifting towards more general hay and floral bitterness as the taste goes on.  Dry, cereal finish.

A thin rusty amber.  Spotty foam, thick around the rim, in beige.  Fat munich aroma  of caramel and brown sugar-dipped raisins.  Doughy, and warm, with a fulsome, nutty malt character beneath the sugars and pitty fruits.  Almost wine-like with a temporanillo texture at times.  The right malts rightly balanced.

Flavor is chunky and deep.  Figs, raisins, brown sugar, molasses bread, and softly cooling spices.  Alcohol present and calm.  Malts staying quite bready, and there’s a slightly herbal touch of hops that lingers near the back, but the syrupy quality of the sweetness tends to whisk that away.  Dirty sugars of maple syrup, and unfortunately, corn, which seems woefully out of place amidst the rest of the malt flavors, which are genuinely well-formed.

Full palate; soft, and oily, even greasy, almost.  Finishes on candy sugar, vague fruits and some hickory wood barbecue tang.  Honey marinade, and sugar cookie dough.  For the most part the beer seems too blonde; while the malt structure seems so firm and polished, it hollows out a bit into sugar and lets the alcohol through too readily.

6-16-08 bottle shared with lb4lb thanks to ogglethorp 
Thick orange amber brown with a decent ivory creamy head.  Smell is sweet dough and alcohol and maybe a hint of raisins.  Flavor is caramel, alcohol and malty alcohol.  Thick with a medium body.  Overall just too boozy and not balanced.
Pours reddish gold, with a huge head that dissipates instantly. Aroma is caramel and sweetness.Flavor is very good rich and caramel like.With malty spicy characteristics.

Bottle, thanks to after4ever! I’m cleaning out the office today, and found yet another ancient tasting note. Pours hazy copper with an off-white ring of foam. Caramel and oxidized apple nose. The taste is mostly caramel and bread until some smoke and spice show up in the finish.

Bottle courtesy of ogglethorp. Thanks!
Pours rich maroonish brown with a light beige head.  Smell is oddly tart and sweet, soy sauce laden malt.  Taste is slightly tart, with a milder flavor than the nose, which is good, considering Im repulsed by the smell.  Toasty, tart malt with a bit of an Oktoberfest like feel to the malt, and perhaps a touch warming from the alcohol.  Not sure if its supposed to taste this way, or is just old.  Medium to rich bodied with light but prickly carbonation.  Not a badly made beer, just not for me.
bottle. dark amber with no head.hop aroma plus slight yeast smell.thick and creamy to the palate.sweet malt tastewith a hint of nut at finish.

In short: A fruity, bready and slightly spicy beer.  Not what Im used from a Doppelbock but really interesting
How: Bottle 12oz from HogTownHarry, thanks a lot Harry!
The look: Cloudy orange brown body with a small beige head
In long: Red apples and nuts wrapped in spicy caramel spread over a crusty bread.  Somewhat vinous.  A pleasant light spiciness.  Theres more that just a biscuit malt profile in there, this is a big cookie of a beer.  No alcohol presence whatsoever.  This is a very solid beer. Its a figure of speech, dont worry, the beer is very liquid.

Pours an amber body with a thin white head.  Aroma is very malty with just a touch of pine and hops in the nose.  Flavor is sweet malt with some pine and a some etoh.  Very smooth with a long malty finish.

Found a few bottle of this last summer and thought I rated this.  Going from memory here.  The bottles were chilled when I bought them, but they were a couple years old and I think it showed a bit.  Great red/orange pour.  A bit brighter than other doppelbocks Ive had.  Lots of caramel malts in the nose.  Some slight metallic character as well.  No real estery fruityness that others have mentioned.  Flavor was similar - very good malt character, a bit nutty, but it just seemed like something was lacking and it was def. a bit oxidized.  Still, easy to drink & abv was hidden well.  I would like to have this fresh.

Reddish Orange, mellow aroma of toasty caramel and a touch fruity. Taste is smooth and sweet - Rye brread, maybe some whiskey-like notes, perhaps some brown sugar, too. Perhaps even some chocolates notes, too. Sampled at Raleigh WBF.

Tastey brew! Wild ABV, but is concealed fashionably in the sweet well balanced taste of this firey brew. Pours a beautiful copper colour with a big amber coloured head. chewy mouthfeel, rather full actually and sweet like caramel, nuts and toffee.

Roughly 3 oz. pour from a 12 oz. bottle, consumed at a beer tasting on 4-12-08. This has been aging in my cellar since the fall, and it has sweetened considerably since I had it fresh. I like it more in some ways and less in others; overall, the effect of about 6 months of aging has been a wash. Sweet, toasted malt aroma. Red apple, red grape, fruity wine, and fortified wine (especially cream sherry) scents. Pours a clear amber with beige head. Sweet taste features nut and peanut butter flavors. Medium to heavy body. Smooth, almost oily, in the palate. I am less impressed with this beer today than I was before I seriously and somewhat systematically started exploring beer.

Color reminiscent of a dust storm during an Arizona sunset.  Shades of rose, burnt orange, and sand.  Aroma is brown sugar, buttermilk biscuits, and citrus...with a flavor that matches.  A little thin for the style.  Very tasty...would be a session if not for the surprising ABV.

Pours deep fiery red (hence the name) with a rather small head. Aroma of luscious caramel malt...slightly fruity...medium mouthfeel. It definitely lingers around your mouth and kicks your taste buds around a bit...definitely spicy (again, hence the name). Careful though, a couple of these with 8.5% could put ya on your keister if you dont know what youre dealing with. Topnotch brew.

Poured an amber color with a nice sweet nose. Flavor for a dopplebock was slightly different. It was caramel sweet but had some fruit flavors chasing it down.This was quite interesting.A nice balanced, sweet finish.

Bottle from Gillard. Badgers suck, you rule. Amber colored body with a darker brown heart. Tan head, 1 finger thick. Good retention and spotty sheet lacing. Nose of toasted sesame seeds, malts, tropical fruits and some floral/perfume sweetness. Also get some doughy notes in there as well. Fore is more of the toasty fruit notes, with a nice full malt backbone and some additional sweetness from the floral hints. ABV is well hidden, I dont make any mention of it in any facet of the beer. A toffee sweetness wells in the back of the throat throughout the consumption of the beer. Medium-full bodied, slightly sticky and substantial. Average carbonation. Dough, sesame seeds and toasty malts on the finish. Very well done.

12oz bottle. Sweet aroma to go with an orange/red brew with a small disappearing head.  Lively palate, though somewhat syrupy.  Light hoppy, tangy finish.  Tartness as it warms, some apple in there.  Pre ratebeer.com this was always my favorite fall and winter brew.

UPDATED: JUL 4, 2009 12 ounce bottle. Poured a hazy amber color with a .5 finger width tan head. The aroma consisted of a lot of caramel and apricot with other sugary fruit in the barkground. The taste was about the same as the smell with a lot of caramel coming through as the beer warmed. This was a very tasty beer, but was almost too sweet for my taste.

Mar. 2007 - Beer poured dark amber color, cloudy with one finger head which dissipated quickly. No lacing. Flavor was caramel, fruits and tons of candied sugar. Beer lacks the earthiness of the really good dopplebocks. Enjoyable, but not great for a doppelbock.
Bottle. Reddish amber colour with a white head. Aroma of caramel and toffee. Nice smooth flavour of caramel, very tasty and nice., but nothing overwelming.

The aroma on this brew is great. It has a strong malty scent. The great thing about the aroma on this beer is that it smells almost exactly like that smell that permeates the air as you walk up to any brewery.... with notes of caramel (respectively). The beer pours clear with a pretty dark red color, Ive seen many hues of amber, oranges, and reds in beers, but this has a different hue than I have ever seen, very nice. 
Pours with a generous white head that diminishes but for a small head that sticks around. 
Taste is fantastic. Very malty, just very lightly fruity some good cherry flavors, it is however predominantly dry with some bitterness on the sides of the tongue. This glass is served a little cold, so the alcohol does show itself; this is pleasant enough as it is in no way overpowering. However when served at room temperature (as I have in the past) the alcohol is very much hidden. 
The palate is smooth with good carbonation feel in the mouth. 
Overall a nice beer, recommended if you can find it.

(Bottle) Pours a dark amber color with little head. Thick, malty aroma. Sweet caramel and solid toffee notes. Also some nutty undertones. Carbonation is on the low side, with a very good palate. Only slight alcoholic warming. A very good beer.

Bouteille 12oz, courtoisie de Hogtownharry. De couleur ambrée-cuivrée et légèrement voilée. Nez fruité (moyen de prunes et de dates, notes de raisins), malté de caramel légèrement rôti et terreux, de pain et de biscuits, léger de houblon floral et aux notes herbeuses ainsi que des notes épicées (poivre), dalcool doux et de noix. Moyennement ronde en bouche avec un pétillement moyen et une texture riche et sirupeuse. Goût de levures fruitées (prunes, léger de dates et de raisins vineux, traces dagrumes) avec un léger goût épicé (cannelle, traces de réglisse noire) lors de lentrée en bouche auquel se rajoute un goût malté sucré de caramel moyennement rôti et aux notes terreuses (traces fumées), léger de biscuits et de pain ainsi que des notes de chocolat et de sucre brun parallèlement à un léger goût dalcool doux et réchauffant puis en finale lon retrouve un goût moyen-léger amer de houblon floral aux notes herbeuses, un moyen goût de noix asséchantes et de petites notes épicées (poivre). Post-goût moyen-long et sec, moyennement amer de rôti, de houblon floral-herbeux avec un léger goût de noix et de fruits (moût de raisins, pelures de prunes) ainsi que des notes dalcool.
Bottle. Pours a light amber with a small white head. The aroma is mostly malts and grains. The taste is also quite malty and grainy, with some hops and light fruit flavors. Overall, a good beer.

[724-20071001] 12floz (w/ jerc, Radek Kliber). Hint of fruity floral hops aroma. Hazy, brown red body with a medium-lasting foamy off-white head. Belgian yeast flavour is not too heavy, has some grainy dough. Medium-full body. Quite nice.

Smells of big sweet malt along with some hefty grain. Taste is big on the malt and is almost like an imperial Octoberfest if such a style existed. Alcohol is tasted a little on the finish. Medium and smooth in the mouth. Drinkable yes, but borders on a session beer, more of an after dinner treat.

Pours an amber to caramel copper with bubbles along the side and no head to speak of, rather clear.  Lightly sweet toast with fruit.  Light doppelbocky.  A bit acidic maybe.  Subtle floral to peppery hops.  Light body, lower carbonation, drinkable.  Toasty and lightly sweet.  a bit fruity and slightly floral in hops.  Rather dry for the style.  a little tannic.  alcohol comes up with warming.  Not bad.

Good, but not an amazing brew. Perhaps Im missing something here. The nose is a rather uncomplicated bit of caramel/malt fluff. Sitting in the glass its a pleasant burnished brass color with the barest bit of a head. The flavor is a caramelled malty combo mingling with bread pudding. Very, very mild hops in the finish.

Pours a clean reddish amber color.  Aroma is very interesting; hint of caramel with lambic complexity, biscuits, and malts.  Taste is sweet and caramel/syrupy with some carbonation.  Finishes off rather malty.  Quite enjoyable.

Bottle. Fairly simple aroma. Sweet, sticky caramel with a hint of maple syrup. Pours firey copper with a thin white head that disappears quite quickly. Sweet initially, but finishes with a boatload of dry, grassy hops. Really, nothing spectacular. Medium bodied. Finishes quite grassy, earthy and dry.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2008 [Bottle, Cellars Tasting] Pours amber with a beige head. Aroma is quite sweet with a lot of malt and some caramel. Taste is also fairly sweet with the same malt and caramel and also maybe a hint of spice. Medium mouthfeel.  A very solid doppelbock.

Bottle from JPDIPSO, thanks! Been wanting to try this brew. Thick amber pour with small off white head. Malty sweet biscuit aroma. The taste was the biscuity and caramely with some brown sugary notes.. Light dark fruit flavor show up now and then. Rich, thickand smooth on the palate. Really a soild. beer

Bottle courtesy of HogTownHarry. Dark copper-amber with a small off-white head. Nice aroma, full and sweet, with notes of caramel and dried dark fruit. Full mouthfeel, a bit sticky in the finish. Well-rounder flavour, quite sweet - caramel malt, brown sugar, a bit of chocolate, and a faint spicy note in the finish. I didnt check the style or the alcohol percentage before I drank it, so I had no preconceptions, and really enjoyed it.

Courtesy of Gillard. Pours a clear deep copper with thin white head. It has a mild aroma with dates and beats and mild caramel sweetness. The flavor is sweet with creamy caramel and fruitiness from dates, prunes, faint beat sugar and hints of pepper. Overall pretty sweet.

Pours a clear amber, with a small off white head.  Smells of sweet malts, caramel, candy sugar, and a little banana.  The flavor was extremely malty, very syrupy texture, with some dark sweet fruits in there too.  The flavor was quite standard, but big, thick, and rich on the palate.  Maybea little overrated, but still a solid brew.

Copper with creamy, tan head / Malty, caramel nose / Medium, winey body with some hops and good finish / Rich flavors of burnt sugar, toffee, with hints of citrus and pine / Seems even bigger than it its.

Wow. Very impressive smooth taste. Hints of the holiday season in this neat little dopplebock.
Malty, with a hint of carmel. Scent: fruity, but now overpowering.  Spicey and woodsy overtones.

Bottle pours reddidh brown with almost no head. Aroma very faint of sweet malts with mild bitterness. Very light carbonation, has a very smooth nice mouthfeel. Taste has caramel malts with little spices. Allspice and woodsy thanksgiving spices. Body is not too heavy. Very pleasant delicious sususpecting beer.
this was impressive.  lots and lots of caramel malt and chocolate malt.  this was cinnamon and hazelnut, with orange, pine and grains.  Yum, surprisingly smooth.

I am not the biggest fan of doppelbocks, and I found this one to be very enjoyable, which I would call high praise.  This beer had a very nice blend of malt character (not too much, as is frequently my opinion of this style), just a bit of cerealness, and a very pleasant mouthfeel.

It poured a rich caramel color with a thick tan head.  Aroma was malty, with a bit of caramel.  Flavor was pleasingly sweet, but not overwhelming, maltiness.  There was just a touch of cereal-ness, which is what I typically object to, but it was in a very nice moderation in this beer.  Mouthfeel was smooth, substantial, and good.

I would definitely recommend this ber.

I had this on-tap at the Palm Tavern in Milwaukee.

Virtually no head; yellowish rim over foxy-red copper beer. Extremely fruity nose: oranges, strawberries, peach, ending on mild lemon & caramel. Specially the strawberry aroma is very prominent. Very cake-like, toasted with caramel, soft rich Belgian buns. Fruity notes are more subdued than in the nose; flavours as from Maillard, scorched breadcrust & bitter oranges. Burning MF, alcoholwarming. Not very bodied for a Doppelbock. Not bad, but quite sweet; rather fierce but thinnish Doppelbock. Thanks to beerboy!

Bottle 355 ml
Appearance :Thick amber haze with tick creamy, slightly tanned top. Nose :Rich ,pleasant fruity aroma. Sweet raisin , rich plum , clean sweet malts blended with dose of refined alcohol.7+ Flavour/Palate : Medium bodied . Solid malt base. Clean and smooth , slightly creamy finish. Fruity rich malts. Slight warmth shown at finish. Good quality straight old school brewing.

Bottle. Hazy brown body with a small beige head. (3+) Moderate sweet malty aroma. Similar flavour of sweet malt, toasty caramel. Average smooth palate. Nice but not knock your socks off. Bottle from HogTownHarry.
Had on tap at the brewery. Pours a light brown color with small head. Nice malty/sweet aroma.  Great malt and spice flavor with a nice touch of hops as well. Very interesting dopplebock!
A very peculiar doppelbock. Quite spicy with pletny of sweetness. Nice and smooth, very different, very tasty.

Light brown with a light tan head.  Aroma of raisins, prunes, caramel, and brown sugar.  Sweet flavor of dark fruits (raisins, prunes), caramel, a hint of molasses.  Spicy hops (Hallertauer?) are hard to pin down, but serve to dry out the finish.  No alcohol apparency whatsoever.  Very good.

12 ounce bottle. Mug. Dark amber with a small tan head. Aroma - Malt, caramel and spice. Flavor was rich and malty with some caramel and a hint of dark fruit. Nice subtle alcohol bite as it warms. Compares favorably with some of my favorite German doppelbocks.
Bottle. A dark amber beer with a big beige head. The aroma is of caramel malt, light roasted, the taste is sweet caramel malt, and hops. Medium body with a sweet finish.

This dopplebock pours a amber orange gold color from a 12oz bottle. Medium sized white foamy head. Aroma is caramel and sweet touch of bread. A medium bodied dopplebock. The malts are fruity, caramel and fairly sweet. The hops are floral and earthy. Nicely balanced. Good carbonation. A touch sticky. Nice beer, It really hides the 8.5% well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly sweet.

UPDATED: OCT 15, 2012 Had this on tap at the Map Room in Chicago. Deep amber body, very malty aromas of caramel. Flavors of caramel and toffee malt combine with light hints of floral citrus, yeast and lighter hints of roasted smokiness and spice lay underneath. Medium length. A great football beer, sessionable considering its high ABV, and ultimate Autumn beer to consume with a spicy bowl of chili.

Appearance is a clear copper body with an off white head.  Active bubbles race their way to the top and then spread out like they are alive.  Aroma is heavy caramel, with some spices such as cinnamon and nutmeg.  A good doppel, upper tier within the style.  I would like to see how this compares to celebrator sometime.  Thanks Islay for picking this up for me while in Wisconsin!
On tap at Map Room (Chicago). This dark amber ale poured with a nice beige head, eliciting a very malty aroma. There is a carbonated mouthfeel and a hoppy citrus finish.

Pours a bright burnt orangish reddish brown, with no head.  Nice musty sweet malt on the nose, with a hint of biscuit and floral hops.  Very full flavor with a nice sweet malt bite as well as a good dose of alcohol and roasted smokiness.
user_location: Farewell Minny; Hello Puyallup, Washington, USA

text: Tasted 7/14/07.  12oz bottle.  Filtered with a deep ruby hue.  Moldy off-white head.  Grapey plum aromas.  Cinnamon spicy and toffee aromas.  Nice nose.  Medium to full bodied with sticky smooth malts.  A bitter astringent citrus alcohol middle.  Finish is sticky with a mild toffee graham cracker flavor.  Moderate effervescence.  The bitterness really starts to shine as it warms.  Decent burn.  Solid brew.

Pours a rich amber/orange with a minimal light orange head that turns into a nice frost on the top.  Thin bodied beer that had aromas of dark fruits, dates, raisins, and some apricot, rich sweet malts.  Taste of richly smoked malts and sweet malts.  Good carbonation and a sweet malt aftertaste.  A good dopplebock in any book.
Pours amber with a moderate, white head. Aroma is very malty. Solid mouth feel with a strong, relatively sweet malt characteristic. A light hop bitterness accents this beer well.
From 33 cL bottle. Pours light hazy red/orange with a light white head. Caramel malty and metallic aroma. Slight sweet malty and metallic flavoured. Finish is sweet to dry malty.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Courtesy of JCapriotti. Clear, amber golden with a yellowish head. Aroma of burned malt. Quite full-bodied with rich, sweet caramel notes. A discreet bitterness in the finish. Nice. 290607

Bottle. Average creamy beige head that mostly diminished. Good display of lacework. Cloudy looking body with an amber color. Aroma of bread, grain, caramel, fruit. Medium bodied with an average carbonation. Moderated sweet malty notes with light bitter flavor. Light sweet finish.

I guess I wasnt quite as impressed with this beer as most others.  It had some additional flavors as compared to msot doppelbocks-- and Im not sure if I liked it or not.  It almost reminded me of a marzen/Octoberfest flavor profile.  A good overall beer-- but I might need to try this again with fresh taste buds to give a better review.

(Bottle via trade with <A HREF=http://www.ratebeer.com/ViewUser.asp?UserID=2 target=blank>CaptainCougar, thanks Tom!) Aaahh, nuthin like a good doppel...Pours quite cloudy darkish amber-orange with a thin biege head that disappears to a thin layer. Wondrous sweet malty aroma - rock candy, brown sugar, licorice and vanilla, plus hints of pine. Mouthfeel medium-full, fairly smooth, a bit sticky. Fine, weepy rings of lacing melt down the inside of the glass. Taste-wise this is a malt-lovers delight - has that bit of smokiness like a Spaten Optimator (one of my favorite doppels) layered over top of rock candy, vanilla and egg cream with hints of darker things like brown sugar and molasses. A light bitter piney hit arrives in finish. Quite a treat.

Chicago Trip. Sunday 16:06. Bottle. Name fits the colour. Deep sunset red-orange. Thin foamy head. Deep malt aroma. Some hops and earthy spice. Rich autumn flavour to start then merges into overripe plum and pepper.

12oz. Bottle
$2.29 Single
Steves Liquor Madison

Autumnal Fire poured a clear glowing caramel brown. A 2 finger khaki head formed on the pour quickly falling to 1 finger that lasts. A glassful of large carbonation bubbles rise to the head. Leaves patchy lacing.

The nose is complex but subtle. Big hint of banana bread off the bat which is definately appealing. Subtle caramel maltiness in the background. Doughiness combines nicely with the other aromas. Every now and then I get a slight metallic twang that doesnt detract from the beer.

Flavor is much the same as the aroma. Banana bread up front mixed with a mild but spicy alcohol that lingers in the back throughout. Caramel sweetness comes through mid palate with the alcohol getting spicier on the finish. Mild fumes rise through the nose. 

Good medium body with a rich texture. Velvety smooth with mellow carbonation. 

For such a high abv this beer is surprisingly drinkable. Enough sweetnees to mask the alcohol without becoming cloying.

Autumnal Fire is an excellent doppelbock from Capital. Enjoyable, easy drinking, and great flavor. The high point, without taking anything away from the flavor, is the mouthfeel.

5/26/07

Bottle from Styles. Clear amber with small off-white head. Aroma is light, some caramel, biscuit, raisins and berry. Flavor is moderately sweet, lots of caramel, red berries, bread and a bit of herbal hops. Medium body has moderate, carbonation and a rough end.
