Bottle, thanks to Hogtown Harry.  Fiery red / copper, thick small white head.  Ok aroma - dusty malt, slight caramel.  Malty taste, thick creamy body, lots of caramel notes.  Not really any hops.  More of a Scotch ale I thought (I tasted this blind without knowing nay about its ranking or style).  Tasty, but just didnt wow me.

Picked up a 12-oz single bottle from Rileys in Madison, Wisconsin. Surprisingly to still find this beer in May 07. Pours a hazy coppery caramel brew with an off-white head. A very fine lacing. Aroma is like a tripel, sweet barely malt, wild cherries, roasted nuts, and sweet apples. Taste is sweet, lightly carbonated, citrus, and a touch of brown sugar. Finish is also sweet with a malt after taste. Alcohol does warm you up.

pours a red, orange, copper color with a huge three finger tan, creamy, solid head. aroma is malt, hops, and a little smoke. has a light to medium body with good lacing and carbonation. flavor is roasted malt, a little hops, and some caramel. has a small dry hop aftertaste and a somewhat light syrupy mouthfeel. also is a little sticky on the lips. has a small burn going down the throat. i guess it is a descent beer for me a little weird and hard to rate as a hop head. i also noticed a little peppery taste and it is definitely a good looking beer.

Bottle from shigadeyo! Nose is vanilla, candi-sugar, caramel,a nd some roastiness; hazy rust color with a medium straw colored head; flavor of some alcohol, caramel, a touch of hop bitterness, and some dark fruitiness. Enjoyable brew!

Slightly hazy pretty ruby body. Slowly receding off white head. Lacing is sparse and light. Aroma is of plentiful toasted grains, light smokiness, candied caramel, molasses, licorice, fruits and maize. Toastier, with more caramel in the flavor. Very believable authenticity. Additions of apricot and mustiness. Smoke is still light, slightly sweet. Bitterness is low. Palate is medium-full, a touch sticky. Finishes full bodied, lightly sweet. Alcohol is masked throughout quite marvelously. Nicely done.
Copper/amber, with an off white head. Aroma is dark fruit, caramel, and malt. Flavor is caramel, fruit, and malt. Fairly heavy body. A nice sipper...

Pour is a dark caramel color that forms into a decent head that faded pretty quick. Smell is ok, lots of malts in it. Plums? Taste is that of a solid Dopple, almost sweet with the fruits. Very drinkable brew.

Courtesy boboski. Clear amber/ruby and a short lived white head. Nose of rich, bready malt, dark fruits, licorice candy, earth, airy yeast. Flavor adds toffee and cocoa powder. Medium/full body, balanced carbonation. Very tasty, well done doppelbock.

Bottle as trade with shigadeyo. Poured hazy dark reddish brown with a large light brown head that diminished slowly with good lacing.  Good caramel toasted tart fruit aroma. Medium body with a sticky texture. Good well balanced tart fruit malty flavor with a moderate smooth balanced finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable beer.

12 oz bottle. Poured pretty thick. Clear dark orange in color. Head was off white with good retention and lacing. Strong malt dominated aroma with toffee, molasses, apple, and alcohol. Warm and somewhat sweet on the tongue. Boozy and malty like molasses and rum. Not bad, but not my bag.

12 oz bottle from KingpinIPA.  Thanks for the brew.  This beer is awesome.   Big, bold Amber color.  Almost looks Neon.  Aroma is a lot like a scotch ale - roasty coffee and whisky.   Taste is like caramel, toffee, scotch whiskey and brown sugar all mixed  together to make a fine beverage.  I could drink this daily.

Rich clear red color.  Big wheat/bread aromas.  Some purple fruits, plum, and prune in the nose as well.  Alcohol is very apparent but you cant expect any thing less from a doppelbock.  Reminds me of a light scotch almost.  Sugary sweet taste with some caramel in the middle.  Overall an interesting and moderatly complex beer.

Thanks to bu11zeye for this beer.  Poured a brownish red with a fizzy off-white head.  Rich aroma of scotch whiskey, molasses, caramel, and a touch of alcohol.  Flavor is very complex.  It starts out with a syrupy sweetness, which quickly yields to some citrusy tartness, whiskey dryness, and some notes of toffee and a touch of alcohol, but not nearly enough to betray the beers strength.  Finishes dry with a few final molasses and citrus notes.  Body is pretty full.  Im not sure if Im getting "doppelbock meets octoberfest" out of this, but what I am getting is that this is a rich, complex, and whiskeyish doppelbock with a bit of a refined air to it that makes for some excellent drinking.

Bottled. A hazy amber beer with a rim of beige head. The aroma is malty with notes of caramel, as well as some oxidation. The flavor is sweet malty with notes of fruit and caramel, as well as a light note of oxidation.
A fall favorite.  Amber pour with a little head.  Sweet malt flavor in the body with various spices.

Bottle. Pours a clear deep amber-brown with a good size mostly-lasting creamy tan head -- quite nice. Mild somewhat sweet aroma of caramel malt, butterscotch, nuts, dark fruit, bready yeast and faint hops. Aroma may be a little mild but theres a big malty flavour along with traces of nuts, chocolate, yeast, alcohol and some light hops in the finish. Not overly sweet which is nice. Medium bodied, syrupy mouthfeel. I must say, I really enjoyed this, very well done!

12-oz., thanks to Secret Santa. W00t! Medium butterscotch-bolored pour; brownish-clear with a light smattering of tannish head. Big caramel and butterscotch nose. Tingly carb. Forward attack, especially considering the beautifully restrained flavors across the mid-palate. Some smoke in there with the caramel and butterscotch as it moves across the mid palate. Sticky and lightly bitter, herb/spicy finish. Fantastic stuff; amazing balance.

Bottle courtesy of Sammy: Poured a medium to deep clear brown color ale with a medium foamy head with average retention but good lacing. Aroma of sweet malt is more reminiscent of a barley wine then a doppelbock but is interesting nonetheless. Taste is dominated by sweet malt with some very subtle cloves but no banana notes can be found here. Body is about average with some medium carbonation and no alcohol is discernable. Overall, this was more akin to a barley wine then a doppelbock but was quite enjoyable nonetheless.

Light-colored, coppery body with a very thin head.  The aroma is sticky sweet - with lots of rich malts and cotton candy.  The alcohol is pretty well-hidden by the sweetness.  The flavor is pleasantly malty enough, with a small bit of hops to make it well-balanced, despite the initial sweetness.  A breadiness abounds.

Bottle from Ughsmash (thanks, Jason!) - nice bring orange/copper pour, with moderate lacework - quite herbal and hoppy in the nose, at least initially, followed by some caramel notes, munich malt, buttery/nutty hints - and interesting take on a doppel - you can really taste the oktoberfest influence in the slightly higher hop profile and mild floral notes - the caramel sweetness one would expect is there, too, and the higher bitterness and mild spice actually balance the beer quite nicely - finishes mildly sweet and floral - nice.

Coming from one of my favorite styles did expect much, i was wrong.  Poured a darker amber color with small head and not much lacing.  Aroma was nutty,roasted caramel and bready.  The roasted malt flavor dominated with bready and nuttyness coming out as it warmed.

Nose of rubied cherries and lots of pale malt cream. Plenty of sweetness in dates and figs abound. Otherwise a fairly standard lagered malt musk. A nice clear firey pour, with a red core and golden-orange fringe. True leaf color. Rim of silky white. Flavor is a warming sweet malt, with lots of Munich character, rising fig reduction, pear candies and a rather hot alcohol. A little muskmelon and candied apple shine over the grain husks and light woody notes. Stays sweet and warm down the back haul, with sugars smacking to the end. Not a whole deal of hop balance, save for a crisp reminder on the top of the mouth. A fair dopple.

Poured an amber to orange color nice initial off-white head, weak retention, only ok lacing. Aroma was dry roasted caramel and nutty malts, lots of dough. Flavor was strong malts, dough, toasted caramel, nuts, faint grass, and some lighter fruits (grapes?).Finishes with a slight hop accent. Mouthfeel was moderately thick, but pretty drinkable. This is one of the best approaches Ive ever had to a lighter doppelbock category (not quite a blonde, but it was a dunkel) of beers, alcohol was silent, it didnt grass hop everything up. Its like they started with more of a Vienna base than a pilsner base, very much appreciated here. The run from Winter Skal to Oktoberfest to this was ordered and themed quite nicely.

Golden raisin color.  Aroma of caramilized raisins, campfire smoke and dried apricots.  Taste is more of same.  Too sweet and alcoholic at first but warms up nicely.  Dry finish that does not linger long.

UPDATED: SEP 7, 2008 12oz, pours cloudy amber with small white head. aroma is mainly brown sugar, cookie, and floral hops. taste notes are toffee cookie, and maple syrup. feel is a tad thin, fizzy, and alcohol warm on the way down. although i got used to the sweetness of this beer its a bit much at first. a nice doppelbock.3.7. 

cellar aged 1 year. wont adjust rating since Capital brews beer meant for consuming fresh. nose is mostly toffee and some cookie. flavor is very malty, toffee, toasted biscuit, and cookie finish. the hops have faded but those never played a big role in this beer. the malt seems to not be quite as robust as it is fresh which perhaps is why this doesnt seem as sweet. dont notice the alcohol either. this beer really hasnt changed much, i wouldnt say its better, but maybe not worse either. didnt notice any oxidized notes though. kinda curious to see it at 2 years but do i have one in the cellar? not sure...A solid doppelbock at a fair price! 

9/6/08, Fall ’08 vintage. $7.99/sixer for such a nice balanced malty and delicious Fall/Winter brew, wow what a deal. There are only a few American and German doppelbock that are better and in the states this is easily the cheapest. sweet caramelly, nutty, dark fruity, nice subtle floral noble hop character,  not too sweet or boozy, yummy lager! this ’08 vintage is much improved, much less sweet and boozy, the feel isn’t fizzy as noted before. 3.9.

Pours a beautiful copper/amber in my chalice.

A little under in the smell department. I have gotten more malt sense in the nose from other doppels, but none the less they are not hugely floral beers, so I understand its lacking.

The taste is absolutely delicious, I love its early easy toffee, and its silky hop balance. I could easily drink an unhealthy amount of this beer. The balance gives the ease of warm bread.

The mouthfeel is smooth and silky.

The drinkability is unreal. This is the ultimate German-style session beer.

App: Deep copper with full tan head, good lacing on the glass
Smell: Roasted Maltiness
Taste: Malty, sweet caramel. Good warm qualities
Mouthfeel: Full body. Spicey cherry like finish
Drinkability: Great Aftertaste. Another great Dopplebock from Capital Brewery.

Pours a hazy auburn color with no head or lacing. Mildly sweet in the aroma. Very thick and sweet malty flavor – although super sweet, it is not cloying at all. Very clean lager characteristics. The aftertaste blends into mild spiciness and hops. Super rich.

Very full body, gentle carbonation. Definately a sipper

Bottled sample via my friend Trevor. Copper in colour with low carbonation. Aromas of plums, mild citrus, rich and malty caramel, banana bread, and a bit of alcohol. Solid toffee flavors, with notes of cinnamon (and various other spices), stone fruit and a bit of minerals. Starts off fairly heavy bodied, but has a mildy bitter finish that balances things out. Good stuff.

Spices, some heat, and grain in the aroma.  Pours ruby red and brown with a thin off-white head.  The palate is full and chewy.  Warm malts and seasonal spices dominate the flavor profile--just a hint of clove.  Interesting flavors--and enjoyable.
Most dopplebocks taste the same and this is no exception.  However, it had a rather nutty character to it.  8.5% was well masked, too.  Pretty good dopple for america.
pretty much like any dopplebock.  solid malts, pretty syrupy.  deep red color.
Get some light fruit and spice in the aroma.Pours ruby red with a medium white head.Get some sweet malt in the flavors.Mouthfeel is a little thin with some spices in the finish.

Bottled. Beer is clear, light bronze with a small, white, frothy, mostly diminishing head.

The aroma is malty with moderate notes of toasted grain, caramel, trace of toffee; Hoppy with trace-to-light herbal, grassy notes, trace of resin; Yeasty with a trace-to-light note of cobweb.

The flavor is moderately-to-heavily sweet, moderately bitter with an average-length, lightly bittersweet finish.

The body is medium, the texture is watery-to-velvety and the carbonation is lively.

Bottle. Head is initially small, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is dark amber. Aroma is moderately malty (caramel, cookie, toasted grain), lightly hoppy (grapefruit), with light notes of toffee and gum. Flavor is moderately to heavily sweet, lightly acidic, lightly bitter. Finish is lightly to moderately sweet, lightly acidic, moderately bitter. Medium to full body, watery/syrupy texture, lively carbonation. Not bad, but fairly ordinary.
Bottle: Dark copper color with a tan head. Aroma, caramel and spice, some citrus. Flavor, Caramel, sweet malts, some spice to it, brown sugar. Pretty good stuff.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a beautiful transparent brownish red color with a small white lacing.  Aroma is peachy and cotton candyish with hints of malt,citrus hops and maple syrup.  Flavor is very similar to the aroma and slightly sweet.  Excellent overall.

Bottle.  Poured a nice orange-red with minimal off-white head that would lace. Crystal clear against light.  A sweet malt aroma, hints of raisins, sugar, and a little hops evident.  Taste is very sfeet, seems like sort of a doppelbock light to me.  Finished smooth and rich with nice lingering bitterness.

12oz bottle courtesy of footbalm.  Thanks, Eric!  Clear, orangish-red appearance; off-white head with slight lacing.  Aroma shows belgian sugar, maple syrup, and some citrus; slightly hot.  Medium-to-full, chewy mouthfeel: belgian and brown sugar, citrus hops, and hints of caramel; sugary sweet with lively carbonation.  Medium finish: sugar and cotton candy.

12oz - 2006 - Aroma of cherry, leather, carmel, toffee, toasted oats and molasses.  Pours transparent brown with no head and little lacing.  Flavor matches aroma but is stronger and the alcohol shows up.  Palate is sweet and sticky.  A very tasty doppelbock.
Bought this at Binnys in Orland Park. Awesome beer selection! Fantastic taste. High in alcohol, but didnt drown out the great flavor and aroma.

UPDATED: MAY 2, 2007 Dark reddish-amber pour with light head.  Smooth, sweet aroma of cherries, peaches.  Taste has a rich malt backing that is tough to pick up before it warms.  Sweet fruits and a nice tangy alcohol burn are present.  This is very different from other beers Ive tried, especially lagers.  This satisfies a barleywine-like craving.  My favorite D-Bock so far.

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2007 Sampled from 12 oz bottle on 10/25/2006 at the Junedale Beer Klub meeting...  

Clear, light copper color with an ivory colored head.  Amoma is caramel, some hop bitterness, and a bit of dry alcohol.  Flavor is malt, deep caramel, and alcohol.  Medium body and smooth.  I really enjoyed this beer and will have to sample it again in the future...  Rating:  7  4  8  3  16 = 3.8.

UPDATE (1/02/2007):  Today was a LONG day at work, so tonight is Doppelbock night!  The line up consists of Bells Consecrator Doppelbock, Capital Autumnal Fire, and Two Brothers Incinerator Blonde Doppelbock.  First up was the Bells.  Now its on to the Capital...

Ive been wanting to have some more of this great brew eer since I first had it at a beer tasting back in October 2006.  A friend that lives in the Chicago area was in Wisconsin on business and picked up a 6-pack for me.  Thanks!  -- 

Hazy amber color (on the darker end of the amber spectrum) with a modest tan head.  It has a yeasty aroma at first, but after the head falls more of the  underlying maltiness and some fruit and molasses characteristics become apparent.  The flavor is a bit cleaner than the Bells Consecrator and .  There is also a warming alcohol in the finish.  Rich malty flavor infused with other flavors including sugary caramel (reminds me a little bit of "Sugar Daddy" candy), roasted nuts, and some faint undeterminable fruitiness.  Overall this beer is on the sweeter side, but has a nice bitterness that brings everything into balance.  This Doppelbock is also thicker than average medium-bodied beer and goes down smoothly.  Overall I quite thoroughly enjoyed trying this beer again.  Now Im definitely looking forward to the other 5 bottles left in the pack!

12 oz bottle; 6-pack from friend (hand delivered from Wisconsin!).  Rating:  7  3  8  4  15 = 3.7.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear reddish-copper body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of sweet caramel malt and some skunky hops.  Flavor of caramel and some fruit.
Got this one bottled at the Binnys Oktoberfest in St. Charles, Illinois. Beautiful dark amber pour, strongly alcoholic throughout.

I was hoping for more from this beer.  I just it to be quite stronger then i expected.  I wish i could remember more but i drank it like a week ago.  It was quite smooth but i thought it had an overwhelming taste of alcohol.

Bottle (12oz).  Deep clear mahogany with an average beige creamy lasting head.  A big wave of fresh sweet bready aroma on opening, settles to a a sweet roast grainy malt with mild floral hops, a little alcohol burn and some ripe fall fruit character - elegant, solid.  Taste is much more roast malt than I expected, bread dough, nutty chocolate, very soft floral hops, the alcohol doesnt burn at all, but its there.  Thick, chewy, syrupy mouthfeel, only mild carbonation, medium finish, feels excellent on the tongue.  A truly terrific doppel, well done, sorry I didnt share it but at least I got to drink a whole one.

On tap @ Map Room:  Pours a dark reddish amber with a small off white head that fades to a ring.  The aromas are malty and a little bit of grapefruity hops.  Smooth and medium bodied on the tongue as I roll it around the sweet carmel malty flavors fade to a hint of fall spices and warming alcohol.  Sweet but not too sweet to still enjoy.

12 oz bottle, via Styles.  Pours a clear reddish amber colored body under a small fizzy beige head that faded very quickly.  Aroma is quite odd, alot of fruitiness for a lager, most prominantly peach and nectarines.  Some alcohol, munich malt, and some caramel.  Flavor continues the fruity theme with more peach and macintosh apples.  Alcohol, toffee maltiness, and some figs on the finish.  Mouthfeel is rather thick and full bodied with a slightly sticky finish.  Carbonation is fairly active.  Overall, I really wasnt pleased with all of the fruitiness going on everywhere, it really doesnt jive with a quality lager to me.
I love it.  Deep and rich color, good silky mouthfeel.  smells of roasted malt and a little  brown sugar.  Sweet taste, a liitle chocolate, dark fruit and a hint of spice.  Excellent!
A great beer. Little brother of Capital Eisphyre. Pours a medium slightly hazy amber. Small head that quickly fades. Malty and spicy. Almost had a barleywine type flavor. Very very good.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2006 Full mouthfeel, medium or more body. fruits, spice somewhat roasted malt, toasted yeasty bread note too.  I didnt taste the chocolate that some reviews mention. Brown sugar and carmel like sweetness is more than I prefer but not bad like some other Capital brews Ive tried. The warming 8.5% alcohol content compliments this complex brew and lends a vinous like feel to it. Beautiful looking briew and bottle.

This is a real doppelbock and wow this is real tasty.This is dark ruby red with little head and kinda thick but not overdone.It has a spicy,malty taste and smooth on the finish.They say it is 8.5% but you would never know.Good sipping beer with a warm feeling  to it.CHEERS

UPDATED: OCT 29, 2006 12oz, no date.  Pours a clear copper red with a one finger fading beige head.  Aromas of maple syrup, caramel and toasty malts, nuts, figs, and vanilla.  Very malty and sweet, but not too sweet.  The 8.5% is very well concealed.  Taste consists of basically the same, and the flavors meld very well.  I may be making it up, but I get very light spicy hops, which would be the only addition from the aroma.  Medium to full bodied, moderate carbonation.  Very good brew.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text: 12 oz. Bottle. Sice aroma stands out along with yeasty bread. Nice amber body with of white head. Rich sweetness and some too much spice for me in the flavor. This is a body warmer noicable from the first couple of gulps. Sweet maybe honey taste on palate.

Bottle is probably closing in on a year old. I had no idea it was a dopplebock or I would have drank it sooner. Served in a Duvel tulip (what I have by the computer). Dark copper color with a fine off white head. Aroma is huge malt, dark fruits (raisins, prunes, etc), spice, brown sugar, and hints of dak chocolate. The mouthfeel pretty full at first. The intial flavors are dark fruits, spice, mild roastiness, toast, milk chocolate followed by a rush of mild to moderate alcohol, some bitterness, cocoa, spice, and dark caramel. The finish is lingering malt that is just on the sweet side of being balaced. The finsh is anything but sweet and cloying. Good stuff. Thanks to Eric/Heemer77 for this beer.

Thanks to JPDIPSO for this one.  Pours deep ruby with 2-finger khaki head.  Marvelous appearance!  The aroma is caramel malty, brown sugary, with some nuts and cabernet notes.  The flavor is caramel malty and brown sugary up front, then gets fruity, with some nuts, toffee, cacao, and red winey notes.  Great mouthfeel and great complexity in this one.

Bottle poured a dark redish orange with a strong white head and heavy lacing.
Aroma is sweet and fruity with a big sweet fruity flavor. caramel, sweet candy, thick body.
Sweet warming finish.

Thanks to my UP roommate for this one.  Too bad we cant get this in Michigan -- its really good.  I was expecting an Oktoberfest, but got a barleywine/doppelbock instead, which was a pleasant surprise.  Sweet, lots of hops and malt taste, good body to it.  One of the best beers Ive had in a while.

Thanks to Jeff for this one. Pours out a very nice copper/amber color with not much of a head. Sweet aroma of some fruit and maybe some bread. Taste is very nice, not what Id expect from a dopplebock, but none the less this was a very solid drinkable beer. Sweet fruit notes with some caramel. Solid brew
Color is amber.  I can smell fruit, malt and nut bread.  Almost like banana nut bread.  Tastes a little like it but with malts and a moderate alcohol bitterness at the end.

Bottle. Aroma warm and sweet, caramel malts leading the way.  Pour was a darkened amber with a thin cap. Flavor was yummy, biscuity caramel and fruity taste.  Palate was creamy and full. Overall very tasty.

Picked up on a whim, when I read on the bottle that it was based on an Oktoberfest brew. I actually ended up liking it more than most Oktoberfests; its smooth, flavorful, and had a very appreciable aftertaste.

This beer produces a nice hearty aroma of roasted malt.  It is an amber colored solution that rests under a thick cream colored head.  This thin beer has a mild biscuit taste that fades smoothly and slowly.

Wow what a beer. Found at Discount Liquor in Milwaukee, my old reliable friend. Very rich, warm flavor as its name would indicate, it finishes large and didnt let me down, even after the hype given to it by friends.

Pour is hazy copper amber with a nice thin but pretty off white head...smell is sort of musty with some dark fruits...perhaps a hint of banana?...taste is sweet and malty...lots of bready malt flavors...quick sweet finish...my ass this is 8.5%!!!

Bottle, from trade with Captain Cougar. Good nose, sweet. Fruity, grape, pear, apple. Sourdough. Caramel. Little hazy reddish orange color, small head that faded quickly. No lacing. Bittersweet flavor, like aroma. Kind of sugary. Lite roasty notes in there. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, Sweet fruity finish. Tasty beer, never would of guessed 8.5%. Wouldnt of guessed a dopple either. I definately got the Oktoberfest part. This went down fast.
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: From a 12 oz. long neck brown bottle with no freshness date. Made a good appearance, poured a clear dark copper amber with a large, foamy, rocky pale tan head, good retention and a fair amount of sticky. Had a tasty aroma, spicy baked apple, a little caramel maltiness and whiffs of sweet alcohol. Moderate carbonation and a slick, smooth medium bodied mouth feel, good drinkability. Very tasty, a smooth sweet maltiness, apples, caramel, a mellow nuttiness and a sweet semi-dry fruity finish with traces of alcohol and caramel maltiness lingering in the palate.

Somehow this beer has managed to elude me to this point.  Slightly hazy orange-red body, thin/medium off-white head.  Caramely aroma with toast and hints of dark fruit and earthy hops.  Caramely, cerealy, toasty, quite sweet body.  Alcohol notes peek through the caramel swirls.  Its interesting that the description notes this is "based on an Oktoberfest personality," as the sweet caramels and toast are present, but the beer lacks the heavier raisins and prunes typical of the best doppelbocks.  Nevertheless, quaffable and rich.  Thanks to RooftopRogue for the bottle.

Bottle.  Poured a reddish copper with a very nice head, but dies quickly.  Scents of malt and caramel.  Sweetness covers the alcohol, and the malty thickness of the brew.  Fruit and toffee with some bitterness.  I enjoyed this one.  Thanks to Beervana.

01.19.06  12oz bottle thanks to CaptainCougar.  Looking at the beer its plain to see why they named it Autumnal Fire as it glows a radiant burnished copper with glistening golden highlights.  The head is lofty for a doppelbock, and lasting as a creamy layer of webby foam.    Aroma is full of banana esthers, light hints of bubblegum, some cooked pear, and lots of rich caramel stirred into muffin batter.  Thick, viscous, even unctuous mouthfeel is a delight in all its alcoholic and malty warmth.  Not so subtle overtones of pear, golden raisin, pear nectar, and walnut.  Really a well done beer, and quite worth the wait. Wonderful and balanced combination of flavors.  Thanks Tom!

Thanks to richlikebeer for sharing this one.  Dark amber color with an off-white soapy head that thins quickly.  Aroma of malts and caramel.  Tastes of roasted malts, caramel to sweeten the taste.  Surprisingly good!

another beer I got in a trade and I do not know who sent it. lost my papers that I try to keep track of trades but thanks to the one that sent it.poured a amber, with a off white head that didnt leave any lacing. aroma caramel, fruits that leaned to being over ripe( not in a bad why), roasted malts, didnt pick up any alcohol. flavor, the fruit comes out 1st, than caramel, and malts, with a nice touch of alcohol. good beer.
Amber color.  Thin white head that quickly dissipates.  Aroma of alcohol and what I (a mostly ale drinker) identify as "lager."  Taste is bitter and slightly sweet, with noticeable alcohol warming.

Bottle:  Courtesy of The_Enemy via a bonus package.  Aroma of caramel apples and a hint of alcohol.  Pours a dark hazy reddish-brown with a small off-white head that quickly fades to a ring around the edges of the glass.  Lots of caramel, brown sugar, light raisin, and hints of roasted malt.  Flavor is constant throughout with as light a bitterness as possibley detectable in the finish.

thanks to santa for this. ruby pour with a thin head that remains as a grey ring. caramel and alcohol nose. nice rich plum and toffee flavor. warming, but the alcohol is well integrated. banana moonpie and blackberry finish. very good.
The perfect beer for a cool fall day.  Takes a while to get the whol taste, but worth every minute.
Bottle obtained from footbalm.  Pours red with a very thin head.  Smells of nuts, grapes, overripe fruit.  Taste is of caramel and pepper, but little else.  Pretty one dimensional for a dopplebock.

Nice lookin beer. Warming but the alcohol is well hidden. Nice rich roasted malts on the palate. Has a little bit of chocolate sweetness also. A little bit chewy. Goes down exceptionally smooth. This is one of the better dopplebocks I have had.

Aroma of sweet malt, toffee.  Appears a crystal clear red-copper color with a small cream-colored head that dissipates quickly.  Flavor is caramel-sweet, followed by what tastes like mild licorice and raisin, and finishes with a hoppy bite.  Palate is medium-thick, somewhat chewy.  Overall, this beer is equal to the sum of its parts.  My thanks to joeybgood for this tasty brew.

Pours a rusty amber color.  Smells of malt, caramel and thats about it.  On the initial taste I picked up some licorice but was unable to taste it later on.  Mostly caramel malt and a hint of dark fruit.  Somewhat syrupy.  Thought this was a marzen but was surprised.   An okay beeer.

Pours a clear amber dark amber with minimal carbonation.Nose is rich in caramel and even a little ripe fruit,something resembling Christmas spices. Very nice. I get the caramel but everything else seems to have gotten outta the car. Maybe this is old??

Light tan head that settles fairly quickly. This dopplelbock is a deep, sparkly copper--the color of my grandpas 58 Studebaker truck. Or the color it will be, when I finally get to painting it in factory original Coppertone Metalic. Aroma is deep dark toffee, just a bit of rum,  and a certain spiciness, that made me wonder if there was a chilli pepper or two tossed into the brewpot.  Melt-in-your-mouth smooth carmel candy blending with a staggeringly deep malt character. Full and oh-so-smooth on the palate. This was such a fun surprise. Hezron sent this one to me, and I had never heard of it. I actually didnt even know what style it was when I opened it up. (The bottle doesnt say.) So I had the rare treat of letting a beer for which I had no expectations completely wow me.

Nice auburn color.  Very warm malt flavors. Some nice bitterness in the end.  Overall, I enjoyed this quite a bit.  Not really heavy handed malts, but good enough where it comes through and doesnt taste like a wet paper bag.  Good balance with the hops.  Good easy drinking beer.

12oz Thanks to OhioDad..Yay Scott! Pours a caramel body with a dirty tanish head. Nose is lots of peanutbrittel, tons orf caramel and malt and roasted nuts..hehe...lots of burnt sugar like hues. Taste is a bit flat, very bitter, lots of nuts and malt here as well. very sticky. Hints of alcohol here and there in the nose and taste.

This was served as an amber/orange/vermillion with a small head. Nose of caramel malt with musty undertones. Flavor was spicy with a well-balanced body. Alcohol was not obvious until the finish. There was a bit of discussion as to whether or not this was a Märzen. Ah... they explain it in the description as a Dopplebock based on an Oktoberfest.
<font size=-4>On tap at <a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/illinois/blue-i Tree Inn, Blue Island, IL<font size=-1>

Ah, Duane. Thanks. This was a great brew. Pour was a nice amber, somewhat cloudy, with a fast to go head. The color really match many of the leaves in the woods near my home. Nose was malty and sweet. Taste was malty and sweet, some fruit and . Just a hint of sour, as a compliment. The last few dopples I have had have been to sour-malty-medicine like to rate high. This, however, was great. Med-to full body, good nose and color. Great taste, not to heavy, perfect for an autumn night, watching the fall classic.

Light aroma of caramel and cobwebs at first, changing to dried figs with a hint of spice.  Beautiful ruby red color (its on fire) with a thin, orangish head that fades quickly.  Perhaps the orange in the head comes from the light shining through the red beer?  Chewy caramel and dried fruit flavor with some white chocolate notes in the finish.  Medium body with a creamy/chewy texture that feels really great.  Dont notice the alcohol at all.  Very yummy.

Bottled.  Pours a translucent medium copper with a head that dissapates quickly.  The aroma does not excite.  Smells of a stale sweetness??  Thankfully tastes better than it smells.  Caramel comes through with a bit of a sweet aftertaste.  Hard to believe the high ABV.

copper color thick well laced off white head.  Malty brown sugar  and carmel aroma very malty.  Good creamy full palate.  Tastes of brown sugar and carmel some plums and hints of alcohol.  Pretty damn good stuff.

Courtesy of Bockyhorsey.

Spicy caramel and malt aroma with hints of dark fruits. Tan/orange with a smallish white head and little lace. Sweet and alcohol spicy caramel malt. Dark cherries and poundcake. Very nice flavor here.

12 oz bottle via trade with heemer77 - Thanks Eric!  - Pours copper with an aroma of caramel and spice.  Flavor is kind of odd.  I thought sure this was a marzen when drinking it but now when I come to rate it I recall more doppelbock character.  Very malty.  Caramel, some spice and a touch of chocolate.  Palate was buttery and fairly smooth.  The alcohol was very well hidden.  Interesting brew!

thanks to kms399 for this one.  anticipation was high as I have wanted to try Autumnal Fire for almost a year.  starts out like a marzen with aroma of pumpkin and spice.  even looks like a marzen with a fiery copper body and a fast fading off-white head.  flavor is a combination of a marzen & a doppelbock, big sweet caramel malt mixed with that unmistakable oktoberfest spice.  has a medium body with an almost buttery coating on the tongue.  while I liked this one, I think if I had tried it several months ago, I would have rated it higher.  interesting how tastes change as you drink more beer.

Tap at Bennos.  This beer pours to a dark amber body.  A thin khaki head.  The aroma is kinda Viennay in malt.  Sweet and darkly toasted.  The flavor is nicely toasted.  Dopplebockish.  There is a nice malt and earthy hop.  The palate is creamy, medium bodied, nice carbonation.

12 oz bottle.  Brandy snifter as recommended. Beautiful garnet color with a nice white head that quickly disappears.  Aroma of sweet malt and alcohol.   Flavor is a lot more of the same - sweet malt and alcohol.  I am getting more alcohol present than other raters, but not overly so.  A touch of hops in the finish for a bit of balance.  Another very good beer from Capital.

Bottle.  Sparkly clear copper pour with a very nice initial off-white head that dissipates rather quickly.  Very nice dark fruit aroma with some caramel and earthy notes.  Strongly malt-based in the flavor, too, with the berries, caramel, and alcohol.  Sweet, yet not cloying.  Floral hops really only come through on the finish.  Excellent balance, and went down very easily.

(12oz bottle) Clear copper body topped by a small off white head that almost wholly dissipates.  Aroma is medium sweet, caramel, some cherry, bread, light earthy.  Taste is very sweet, caramel, raisin, some cherry, light alcohol.  Sticky medium body.

12-oz bottle, and on tap at the brewery biergarten
Gorgeous brilliant ruby copper color -- one of the lovliest beers Ive laid eyes on. Medium white head forms on pour and a thin head sits on top until the liquid beneath it is gone. Huge sweet caramel malt nose. Big sweet caramel flavor as well with some alcohol showing, though not enough to betray its 8.5% ABV. Medium hop presence is almost overwhelmed by the complex malt. Mouthfeel almost thin for how intense this beer is. Thick, slightly cloying palate. The best American-made German beer Ive had yet. Consistently excellent year after year, on tap or in bottles. My favorite local seasonal, I look forward to this beer and a trip to the brewery every fall.

Just about as good as doppelbocks come...rich roasted caramel malt and an almost bread-like chewiness.   Others have remarked on the mild hopping, but I get a pretty decent bitter jolt from this stuff.  Alcohol almost invisible.  And a great lingering smooth finish...I love this stuff!

On tap at the Firkin, Libertyville, IL.  Average off-white head with good lacing. Clear red amber color with fruity ester aroma.  Soft carbonation. Medium bodied with smooth creamy texture.  Starts with a light sweet malty taste and finishes slightly dry with light hops. Similar to Capitol Oktoberfest but better. A tasty and unforgettable beer.

Although a dopplebock, this comes across more like an uber-Marzen.  Its a deep orange color, almost red, with a thick, creamy, off-white head.  Its got a heavy, sweet malt aroma, caramel and fresh bread.  The taste is an almost chewy sweet malt with a light roasted flavor beneath it.  Some very light hopping comes along with the sweetness in the finish.  Very drinkable, dangerously so, because the potent abv is well hidden. This is a dandy.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Armanetti, Willowbrook, IL<font size=-1>

Pours a deep copper color with a dense off white head and medium carbonation. Heavy malty aroma similar to a German octoberfest. Sweet malt flavor with hints of toffee and caramel. A lasting sweet flavor is left in your mouth. Very easy to drink, with the alcohol being hidden.

An odd, stale aroma.  Sweet maltiness with a slight alcohol twang.  Fairly low "warming" quality for something dubbed as fire.  Thick and sweet, but not entirely great.  A good doppelbock, but not the best from the Capital stable.

12 oz bottle.  When drinking this I had no idea of its 8.5%abv.  Alcohol is hidden very well behind all the malt.  Pours a deep amber, very clear with a nice thin lasting head.  Aroma is bready and very malty, lots of munich-like sweetness in the smell.  Flavor is also moderately sweet yet not cloying, loaded with malts and finished off with a bit of hops.  One of the brewers (Pat?) who gave me this beer said it was kind of a cross between a maerzen and a doppelbock.  I can see where the marzen comes in with the lighter red color, and more subdued big bready malts and some chocolate that straight up doppels have.  The mouthfeel was in the middle range making this very easy to drink- differentiating it from many doppels which can be almost too thick, sweet, and cloying to drink much of.

GTM. Really bad aroma, macro lagerish. Dark, brownish orange with a large off-white head. Very beautiful beer. Malty flavor. Not sure what the buzz is about. Then again, this was something like beer #25 among the Midwests best beers. Something off in the flavor I really didnt enjoy. If this is Capitals best brew, I confirm my long time notion that either Capital is simply not that great a brewer or perhaps that their Germanocentrric products dont hit home with me.

Sampled at the Great Taste of the Midwest, Madison, 8/13/2005. My wife opted for Octokberfest while I sampled Autumnal Fire, and I was surprised how similar they were to one another. This offers a nice dried cranberry and raisin profile, with a good viscosity on the palate. Great malt backbone gives it is caramel and butter notes. My favorite of the series is still the Blonde Doppelbock, but this is probably a close second for me. Having this spend some time on bourbon would make it exceptional.

In the bottle at the 2005 Bad-burek party. reddish amber in color with an off-white head. Rich toasty aroma with a modest amount of hops. Thick palate with a fruity bitter flavor. Good and chewy without being over the top rich. Unusual beer.
A delightfull combonation of a Doppelbock and an Octoberfest. Carefull....it kicks!

Pours blazing amber color with no head. Huge caramel aroma with some roasted grains in there. Flavor very much the same, with a long lingering grainy aftertaste. Nice syruppy body and mouthfeel. Only grabbed a single, (couldnt find any sixers) but plan on getting some more for the fall. Great for the first brisk days in late Oct/Nov.

Doughy German aroma, amber body, with a short head and good lacing.   Moderate bitter flavor with a syrupy texture.  Probably best in the Fall when the cold winds are blowing over Lake Mendota.    I had no idea what style Capital was going for (not listed on bottle label) until I checked it out on RB.com.

Brilliant orange-amber color and bright peach head that fades rather quickly. The bottom line is that this beer is unique -- try as I might I simply cannot discern aroma/flavor elements other than caramel malt and a touch of alcohol. A bit of hops in the finish. Very full mouthfeel. Not the best doppelbock but at 8.5% certainly not a drainpour.

Nice malt/toasty aroma.  Light sweetness which I prefer.  MAlts are very smooth and has some caramel hints.  Medium body with slight hops and a bit of an alcohol finish.  Just gets better as it warms.

Little or no head,the cap seemed to come off the bottle a littl to easy with no pop at all,sweet malty fruit aroma,pretty much a straight malt honey taste, with just a touch of hop aftertaste. Nice enough, but I cant figure out how it does so well in the Realbeer contest
Red orange foliage with no head. Sweet vinous aroma with light orange notes. Sweet malt and restrained hops with faint vanilla notes. Medium bodied. Jan. 2005.

Thanks to CaptainCougar for this bonus bottle!  Deep amber orange red color, truly a bit fiery in appearance.  Nose of deep caramel, mixed with the light floral notes you would expect in this style.  Pleasant, and Im not even a bit fan of bock beers in general.  Floral hop palate fades into a sweet caramel and molasses tinged finish, with a touch of honey.  Not totally my thing, but enjoyable.  I would think most fans of bock beers would be drooling over this one.

Bottle. Thanks to joeybgood for another one! Pours a gorgeous copper with a small off white head. Light permeates this and it looks like an autumn sunset. Nose is very malty with light alcohol, ripe fruits, honey, and toffee. Smells very rich and very sweet. WOW! Taste is very fruity and sweet with toffee, brown sugar, light alcohol, honey, light spiciness, and syrup. Body is sticky and thick. Leaning towards being too syrupy but is still creamy and slick. Mild carbonation feel. Finish is more toffee, alcohol, honey and malts with light fruit. Indeed a snifter beer!

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2005 On tap at the brewery. They found a keg of this autumn release somewhere, and had it on tap. Dark amber, nearly brown in color. Very little head. Aromas of honey and caramel. It is very thick and syrupy, with coffee, caramel and toffee-style sweetness. There is some spicyness in the finish, although the syrupy sweetness overrides. A little over-sweet in my opinion, but very worth having a bottle or two.

Nil aroma for me.  Amber with some head retention.  Malty semi-sticky palate with some caramel and dried kiwi (note that this is not my first beer of the evening).  Mouthfeel is somewhat thick, and finish is bland hops.  Not as impressed as I should have been....wait a minute! This is 8.5 abv???  Wow! Well-masked--not a hint of alcohol throughout the swallow.  I am now more impressed.

UPDATED: MAR 29, 2007 2004 bottle Huge thanks to Heemer77 for getting this one for me.  Had been wanting to try it for a long time.  Good auburn mixed with amber colored body on it, clear, with a small dark yellow/light tan head.  Fruity notes are given off, as is a thick, robust caramel malt.  Notes of alcohol are well intertwined with the sweetness, producing a fiery, rich smell.  Flavor is much the same, though perhaps even more sweet than the aroma had set me up for.  Sticky, coating caramel and toffee sweetness, with a light fruitiness in the background.  Light creamy maple fudge notes add to the sweetness.  Alcohol attempts to dry out the body, but dosent succeed in doing so.  Spicy notes mix with the candied sweetness on the end and the finish is relatively quick.  Medium body, with more flavor, sweetness, alcohol and hops than the body seems to support.  Not overly complex, but pretty tastey.  The Fish Tale Doppelbock later in the night would prove to be more complex.Aged bottle from Styles drunk in early March 07Not exactly sure how old, but it definitely shows no negative signs of aging.  Actually one of the best German beers Ive had and much better than the more fresh bottle I had.  I guess it couldnt be more than a 1.5 years old as it still poured a large head and was retained well.The flavor and mouthfeel were about as perfect as I can imagine for a doppelbock.  Delicious mix of light fruitiness, vanilla-cream maltiness, slight bits of toffee chewiness, moderate caramel and just a hint of spicy hops (earth, herbs, leafiness, clove) to give it a pinch of bitterness.  Sweetness is perfect.  Enough to give it a wonderful malty-creamy texture but not to the point of being cloying or inhibiting drinkability.  Even a bit of red fruitiness (red apples, berries, cherries) to add complexity.  Breadiness and acidity seem to have vanished (not that they are that persistent in this beer to begin with).  I really like that, who needs all the sourness/breadiness/acidity?  I dont see what it adds, other than maybe a more authentic feel.  Mouthfeel is perfect on this.  I think I drank my glass in 4 sips and almost opened the second bottle that Chris sent me.  Score is for this bottle.

Pours a ruby orange color...very strong sweet malt aroma.  Sweet flavors of carmel and brown sugar.  Nice and warm in the mouth with a hint of bitterness in the finish.  Very nice blend of flavors...good for fall when the leaves begin to change color or as a winter warmer.  Makes a good argument for best beer by Capital.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2005 Minor rating update.  2005 bottle seemed more separated than the 2004 batch - alcohol was more discernable and the balance was a bit more off, thus the rerate where Ive bumped the overall from 17 to 15.  Nevertheless, the 2004 full review...Pours an amber brown, reminiscent of an Oktoberfest. Smell and taste are rightly matched: rich and sweet. This beer matches its description well: a doppelbock with an Oktoberfest personality. Elements of caramel, malt, brown sugar and toasted cinnamon are predominant. This beer is very warming - even coming straight from the fridge, this beer doesnt taste or feel cold - a testament to the subtlety high alcohol-by-volume content. Different, but good. Personally, I prefer Capitals Dark Doppelbock.

Poured a ruby color with a quickly dissolving off white medium sized head.  Other than the head this beer has a soft carbonation.  Matly aroma with notes of figs and raisins.  Malty flavors...dried fruits and sweetness with a semi dry finish.  Hops provide a nice backbone.  Medium bodied and silky.

Pours lite amber with little head. Very sweet heavy munich notes that bring on a nuttiness. Med heavy body.  No hops in the nose or on the tongue. Some serious breadiness and faint whiff of alcohol burn. A little too sweet but not as bad as some Ive tried.

Dark amber body and small beige head. Nose has a vegetal quality left over from the lager yeast I presume. Beyond that, Munich malts are prominent with some classic grape and bread crust qualities. Sweet and malty flavor with an element of brown sugar. The alcohol in this one warms the belly and fogs the mind.

bottle-thanks to the kind people at capital brewery for hooking me up with a free 6pk of this fine lager.  pous a deep amber hue with a small white head.  big aroma of fresh grains,honey, wood chips and maple surup.  big body.  flavors of german malts, spice, sugar candy, dust esters, and some noble hops.  a lilttle fruity on the finish.  very complex.  Thanks again to the fine folks at capital brewery.

Thanks to Tchrome for hooking me up with this beer. I went and grabbed the bottle, cooled it for a half hour and grabbed it out of the fridge. Poured it into my glass and not once really did i look at the bottle. I poured it into my glass assuming this was going to be nothing more than another amber lager...what I find out is Im drinking a doppelbock and it just took me by surprise. The pour is very non-carbonated...headless with no lacing to speak of. Clear deep amber color with an aroma of malt, brandy, and a citrusy apricot. The flavor is very malty, sweet and dry in the finish. Medium to full bodied mouthfeel, non carbonated but very sticky and almost cloying. A slight tinge of alcohol presence, but pretty much non-intrusive. Some nutty, raisiny and fruity orange and citrus peel elements going on here. Very interesting and unique flavor, but overall lackadaisical appearance.
Orangey amber color with no head. Aroma of orange, alcohol and sweetness. Flavor of malt, orange and alcohol. Medium body, liquorous texture, soft carbonation.

Plenty of tangerine-like citrus fruitiness with nutty, marzipan notes in the alluringly sweet and malty aroma with some alcohol apparent.  Clear orange-copper with thin, off-white head that recedes to thin ring.  Still-looking.  Very sweet and simple at first although some minor herbal hop flavour and a strong citrus fruit flavour emerges as it warms.  Medium-light body with decent carbonation.  Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, lubiere, MartinT and Rastacouere.  Thanks, TChrome!

Clear orange comprising red and brown hints. Head is off-white, mostly lasting. Aroma is deep, malty, very fruity and somehow delicately farmy in its herbal and earthy suggestions. Diplomatic and gentle melon, peaches and several fruit notes yet not hiding its substance (8.5% after all). Mango and not quite ready greenish oranges accompany obvious leather tones. Very approachable at first, but developping into a surprisingly bold fruitiness and more alcohol at it reaches room temperature. Medium bodied, light-medium carbonation is appropriate. Excellent and charming doppelbock example with unique characteristics, but is it really better than 95% of the german examples? Further samplings shall tell hopefully.

The Lure:Gusty citrusy earth brushes a mild butter suggestion. Burnt caramel diluted by pure alcohol shots.

The Festivities:An earthy fruit salad with creamy caramel creates a dessert doppelbock. Sparse wheat blades sway back and forth sporadically. 

Transcendence:Dusk settles and paints the sky with warmth.

Somehow, Ive managed to miss rating this beer. No problem, its a favorite, and I wont complain about the chance to drink it again. Dark red color but no head. Apple and caramel in the aroma. This is another one of those beers that I dont mind just sitting and smelling for a bit. Apples and raisins stand out in the taste, above the thick, almost syrupy feel. A very enjoyable beer.

Bottle.  Brilliant chestnut red colored beer.  Head fades quicker than a one-legged man in an ass kicking contest.  Rich malty aroma.  Severely lacking in carbonation.  A litlle cloying with malt sweetness.  Fair, but the bottle I has wasnt in the top 10% either.

Beer pours medium chesnut brown with a moderately dissipating off white colored head.  Aroma is heavy caramel and a hint of alcohol.  Flavor is very nice with nice malt sweetness, caramel, though the bottles I have had seem to be a bit light on carbonation.  Enjoyable, but the bottles I received dont seem to put this in the top 10% of all dopplebocks.

12 oz bottle: mammoth tan, tight small bubbled foamgrowing and then falling with a nice waterfall effect above the rosy gold body.  Streams of garnets rise through the glassmoveable patchwork film settles on top.  Spicy malt aroma with softly grated nutmeg, honey, cider soaked cloves and mushy fruit flesh.  As smooth a palate as any Doppelbock I have tried, creamy with a subtle effervescence that gives the tongue a slight tingleA strong cotton candy sweetness masks a good deal of the alcohol initially while the strong, fruity (apples, pears, raisins, and melons) malts coat the tongue.  A wonderful fall treat on an oddly warm November night in Chicago

Cloudy firey amber color with an initially thick head that settles down to a thin layer of foam. Excellent caramel malt aroma even if one dimesional. Body is slightly creamy and smooth. Excellent flavor also, sweet with caramel and malt with some faint wood and vanilla. Overall one of the best American Doppels Ive had.
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: This was a pint on tap at a local restaurant. ive had this in bottles and was looking for a significantly tastier experience from the tap.  What I got was a disappointing flavor that seemed to be somewhat stale.  Still better than 90% of the rest of the on-tap offerings they had.  Still one of my top 5 beers.  Erod.

The appearance is a orangish brown with almost no head on the pour. The aroma is woody with some cherries and grapes. The flavor is rather sweet with some raisins, caramel, and molasses. The body is a little thin on this but the taste is still quite enjoyable. The aftertaste does hint at alcohol and it coats the tounge. Another good beer from MrFacto!

New bottle: perfectly flat, as if cask conditioned from the handpull. Glazy amberorange. Nose is alcoholic and caramelly. Taste is nutty at first, rich mouthfeel, thick.  Actually all malty and thick, with notes of caramel, nuts, plum, apple and plenty of alcohol. dry finish and nutty aftertaste. A bit strong and flat.

Hazy copper/brown coloured body with a thin off-white head. Aroma of raisins, malt, toffee and nuts. Medium-bodied; Strong malt flavour with cardboard and caramel coming through. Aftertaste shows some of the biter qualities-not bad at all! Overall, very nice to finally try~the bottle is about 1 year old! But it was definitely worth the wait! Many thanks to Mike (BBB63) for the trade for this beer! I sampled this beer acquired from BBB63 on 10-July-2004 on the Eatern Shore of Virginia.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2006 Poured almost a deep rust color with zippo on the head. Aroma of (very)mild caramel and a hint of malt. This pretty much tasted to me like a watered down Salvator Dopple with a tad bit of dryness in the finish. Easy as hell to drink tho. Whoo-pieee!
9-22-06 rerate
Wow. This is way differant from last year. Not real complex  but very good.
 Served at 50 F. Smells and tastes like a mix of sweet malt,very overripe bananas with mild chocolate. Great thick mouthfeel. Nice.

Tap at Clark St. Ale House, Chicago...Dark, no head, smells of carmel.  Thick, sweet and carmel.  Carmel overwhelms any maltiness.  Very sweet and too much carmel.  Nothing like the bottle I had last year.  Too bad.

Pours a chestnut brown with zero carbonation - flat as can be.  The aroma was a little bit sweet, a little bit sour, with pineapple and honey.  The pure malt favor was on the tangy side (as opposed to some smokier doppelbocks).  Lingering sweetness dominates and sticks to the tongue.  The strange part is that the texture is oily, but the palate a tad thin.

Amber mahogany in color with a nice amount of carbonation and lacing.  Malty aroma, carmelly sweet, balanced by nice yeast spiciness.  Some bitterness and plenty of maltiness, caramunich like.  Finishes clean and not too dry, the malt lingers, and the alcohol warms.  This is an enjoyable after dinner beer for sure.
Bottled, thanks cquiroga!  Clear ruby. Warming with loads of thick, roasty malt, restrained sweetness and soft mouthfeel. Low hop rate that puts all focus on the malt character. A good doppelbock.
Amber.  Aroma of malt that so many bocks have.  Flavor is malt and sugar.  Very sweet.  Some caramel.  Alcohol is not found in the taste.

This pours a rich, brilliantly clear chestnut colored beer topped by a creamy off white head.
The aroma is an assertive caramel malt complexity that really teases the nose.
The flavor is complex as well, first a lightly bitter sweetness followed by a subtle blend of smoky maple, licorice and toffee. nice smooth mouthfeel and the alcohol is well hidden in the taste, but which warms quickly.
Thanks to MrFacto for this fine Wisconsin brew!! Very Tasty!!

Bottle Pours a deep mahogany with a dense but short head of pale off-white.  Aromas are mostly dark malts and slight grain, bread notes.  Yum, great malt flavors and dark slightly smokey notes with fairly sweet buttery toffee and caramel falvors as well.  Feel is clean but a bit thin, though not uncharacteristic of the style.  Trailer allows the hops to come more to the front and leave a slightly bitter calling card.     Very nice.  Tahnks again to MrFacto

UPDATED: DEC 4, 2004 Let me first say that I was expecting more. The head was average, and there was little lacing. I liked the colour, it was a nice amber colour. It was a little thin, which suprised me. The flavour was decent, but nothing to write home about. It was a bit sticky and it had a good balance. I guess it just wasnt as flavourful as I had hoped. 
Re-rate: my score on this one was much lower than I thought it should be, so I went back and got another bottle. Malty cider aroma, full smooth body, good head with a nice amber colour. Raisins and cider dominate the flavour. Much better the second time around.

Pours a deep, glowing--dare I say fiery?--red, unfortunately capped by only a childishly inadequate head. Sweet, malty aroma with some floral notes. Big, thick and malty with a surprisingly vibrant hop presence. This is excellent. It stays true to the doppelbock style but has a unique character all its own.

Burnt orange hue, very small ammount of head and no lacing.  Roasted barley and sweet malts in the aromatics.  Flavor is maple, roasted malt & dried dark fruits, a bit of alcohol as well.  Feels a bit light on the palate.  This was pretty good for a doppelbock, however I dont really care for the style in general.

10/8/04.  Poured out of 12 oz. bottle, obtained in a trade with DavidP from RateBeer 10/1/04.  Pours a glistening ruby-caramel color, transparent but seeming slick.  Nice little tuft of a tan head, lingering moderately with some blotchiness and fairly good, lightly patchy, lightly shimmering lacing.  Sweet leafy caramel malt aroma with some spiced pumpkin and superripe banana.  Taste is surprisingly sharply bitter with a tinge of acrid black malt and a sticky sappiness to go along with medium-sharp German malts.  Sweetness and very slight nuttiness, and while theres a lot going on, its not really that interesting or special.  Some mulchy flavors and a touch of acidity as well.  I like the spice, but all of the flavors seems to be parallel and direct, not really overlapping or intertwining in any elegant way, and with very little depth or breadth.  Finish has a haunting butter caramel, a bit too much lingering dark marshmallowy sweetness.  Sticky dried sap on the lips, medium body with a smooth transition to the finish, but the flavors arent exactly what Im looking for in a doppelbock.  I must confess, however, that Im a sucker for the style.  I love me some doppelbocks.  So I guess Id say this is still pretty damn solid, even if there are other doppels I love much, much more.

GABF2004... Poured a copper color with a small off white head and light lacing on the glass.  Aroma of sweet caramel, bananas and various malts.  Lagerish berry taste.  Lots of sweet malts as well.  Seemed to finish almost smokey.  Glad I was finally able to try this doppel that id been looking for, for some time.

Bottled. A refreshing break after tasting Oktoberfests all night. Has a heady doppelbock aroma worth sticking your nose deep into the glass. Not exactly as "red" as other comments have led me to believe, but a rich color nonetheless. Deep and rich bock taste, befitting a GABF medalist.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2005 Pours a dark wine red with a small diminishing off-white head. Aroma is malt and cherries, apples and nuts. Flavor is malt, with a little alcohol, nuts, and more fruit. Malt dominates the palate with a hoppy/boozy finish. A great "autumn" beer!

Bright red with streaks and light orange streaks and a thin, off-white head.  The aroma is strongly malty and quite sweet.  Sticky caramel, light raisin, toasted grains and a touch of chocolate.  The body is slick and full.  The flavor is mostly sweet with the sticky caramel and ripe fruit taking control at the beginning.  Toward the finish a moderately crisp hop bite comes through to make things interesting.  Another solid, tasty beer from Capitol.  Nothing that blows my mind, but something that is easy to drink and perfect for the season.

Bottle pours copperish amber, small  fizzly off-white head, lively carbonation, with fairly slick lacing.   Molasses, raisins, minor vanilla notes, as well as alcohol on the nose.   Figs/dates, slightly sweet, caramel, brown sugar, and light alcohol in the flavor.   Good body, moderate mouthfeel.   Finishes very clean, slightly malty, sweet, with a bit of grains.   This is a damn fine Autumn treat!   Thanks goes out to footbalm for the trade!

Small tan head, fair retention and very little lace. Beautimous, clear amber/red hued brew that glows when held up to the light. Big malt nose, caramelly, candyish. Medium body, lightly coating with a pleasent grainy texture. Bready malt flavors, black licorice, chocolate and hints of alcohol as it warms. A light spiceyness shows up in the medium dry finish. Thanks to jpdipso for a shot at this one!

Apples and spice and the color of falling leaves.  This is hands down one of the best named beers out there.  It reflects the season and mood.  And the beer delivers.  Smooth and rich with great spiciness.  Just the right amount of alcohol hidden in a blanket of caramel malt.  Not quite complex enough for a "brandy snifter" but big enough to make this memorable.
Clear mahogany w/white head. Carmel, malt nose with hints of cherry. Med-heavey mouthfeel w/malty finish. Creamy cramel, toffee, cherry, w/ slight bitter malt finish. Awesome fall session beer!

Deep amber with thin beige head.  Nutty aroma with some caramel and cooked veggies.  Flavors: big mouthfeel!  Milk chocolate lingering bitterness on palette.  In a side by side tasting of oktoberfests, this does not stand out.

Very dark copper coloring, almost brown. Small, slightly yellow head. Aroma of malt, caramel and a little bit of leaves. The taste is sweet with caramel apples and some background of molasses. Almost too sweet. Light and playful on the palate. A sweet change of pace. A real nice fall brew.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2005 Really not fair to classify this as a dobblebock.  These guys invented this style (well commercially anyway).  The 04 version just came out and has some new wrinkles.  A rich tan head crowns this ebony beer, darker than previous versions.  Nice aroma of malts, with a biscuit and toasted flavor.  Sweetness is much better disguised in this version by the balanced hops.  Excellent overall.  I thought the previous versions were a bit too sweet.  This one is much more quaffable.

UPDATED: APR 4, 2007 Thanks Captn C.  Bottle brown and slightly hazy with a off white head.  Aroma is very worty.  Lots of caramel, brown sugar and grain.  Flavor is cloy, but that is the point of a doppelbock isnt it?  Guess what the finish is very sweet too!

Pour is a deep reddish brown. Head is a thin layer of cream.  The aroma is very sweet, yeasty and malty.  The taste is sweet and slightly sticky.  The aftertaste has abit of alcohol heat to it.  Not sure if this is worthy of the 94 percentile rating though.  Thanks to Robertsreality for this interesting brew.

UPDATED: SEP 29, 2004 Resampled thios one because last time I tried it, I was a little trashed, I don't think I did it justice.  Beautiful smell and pour.  Taste starts a bit edgy, but after a couple sips, this becomes very enjoyable.  I could easily drink a 6er of this.

Bottle (thanks to BadgerBen for this trade).  Pours nice deep copper color with a medium sized off-white head.  Rich honey, molasses malty nose with hints of sour fruit and hops.  Nice sweet full malty flavor,  a little yeastiness, alcohol and turning figs.  Full body and gentle carbonation.  Pretty good dopplebock.
This is a nice red brew.  Has a rather sweet aroma with a nice alcohol level to induce the warming.  The after taste is not that merorable though

hot damn, this is a nice brew.  smells sweet and is very similar to a marzen.  bill once again brings it to me with this fine offering.  pretty strong, the 8.5 creeps up slowly with a very nice warming effect.  IMO this is better than celebrator.  very rich and nice.  sticky and oily mouthfeel.  pretty damn good
It seemed kind of vinergary to start but ended up ok, not on the top of my list but this is the first one I have rated.;
UPDATED: JUL 16, 2004 This one has some stank on it!  Tried in Madison.  Fruity. Dark Amber Coloring....you KNOW you just drank this one...
UPDATED: OCT 4, 2012 Very thick pour from the bottle, and a very rich mouth feel throughout.  Sticky oats, wood, corn, burlap and a caramel or toffee/peanut flavor that is hard to classify.

Deep dark sparkling ambers and brown, fizzy off-white head.  Loved the nose on this with notes of chocolate, dough, toffee, cherry and spices.  Got some dark fruits(fig,raisin) for good measure too.  Flavor was rich with hops doing their best to balance.  Full- bodied, fizzy carbonation, smooth, semi-sweet, dry finish.  Very good doppel...

Sparkling clear, burnt orange ale with a small, fizzy, off-white head. The aroma is of milk chocolate and cinnamon. The flavor is well-balanced and heavy with notes of honey and maple syrup. Full-bodied with a silky mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Lengthy, bone-dry finish.

Almost looks like fire!  Rich and deep red-purple color with thin layer of foam.  Absolutely perfect aroma of toffee-cookie and juicy malts.  Flavor is borderline cloying.  Toffee malts are in full abundance, with a thick palate.  A tingle of hops finishes it off within the realm of balance.  Drink fairly cool to ensure that balance.  Mantains drinkability in the face of some of the biggest melanoidins ever!  Not a session beer though.
Dark hazy Copper with large head. Malty aroma. Thick malt, almost syrupy, roast in mid-sip spice, and bitterness.  Guess its 6.5%.  Thanks pigfoot.

Hazy copper thats not quite on the dark end of the copper spectrum. The head starts off dense and nicely sized, but fades quickly. Pours thick. Aroma is very malty, but not much in the hops department. Same goes with the flavor, with the addition of a bit of almost hazlenut. Almost tastes like a spiced winter warmer, but not quite.
Deep hazy copper in color with a small off-white head. Huge sweet malt aroma,notes of bread and toast.Malty sweet and warming.

Very very pleasant.  Pours a caramel nut color with a bit of head, quickly gone.  Sticky, carbonated appearance, mildly syrupy.  Not knowing how this was officially categorized as I was drinking it, I pegged it as a Belgian brown/dubbel/doppelbock.  Good mouthfeel, rich, with flavors of bock malts, caramel, big sweetness, alcohol, and candied apple (something fruity here, at least).  Nicely done.
Hazy deep orange with a nice off-white head.  Deep rich sweet aroma, full bodied and smooth.  Long aftertaste and sweet ending.  A great doppelbock.  Thanks Indra!

Mahogany, large eggshell white head and lace. Strong caramel nose, nuttiness, roast malts, nutmeg and alcohol. Sticky caramel, alcohol, woody, more spices; cinnamon rather than nutmeg, and brown sugar.

Ruby bronze color with tan head and a nice amount of lacing. The aroma is very malty with lots of dark fruits, fig, brown sugar, maple syrup. The flavor has some caramel and more sweetness with a touch of hops. Unbalanced but tasty. Finishes rounded and nice.

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2006 Small off-white head that maintains for a while. Slightly unattractive dark orange/red body. Aroma has lightly hopped carmelly malt, spicy apple, vinous. Taste is sort of a grape-like hops with sweet caramelly malt in the background. Was a pretty enjoyable drink. And the more I have, the more I notice the hop hints. 
Original rating - 3/30/2004 & 10/28/2004 - 8 / 4 / 7 / 3 / 15
Updated 6/12/2006 - 8 / 4 / 8 / 4 / 16
Cream head, slowly diminishing to lace, deep orangish-copper color.  Very malty aroma.  Taste is sweet with candy flavors moderate bitterness at the end.  Smooth.  Very good beer.

Murky orange/red out of the bottle with a foamy tan head.  Very sweet malt/caramel nose.  Honey, caramel, marashino cherries, toffee (it reminded me a little of Ben & Jerry's Heath Bar Crunch), maple syrupy and other sweetness.  Very enjoyable and tastey beer.  Thanks to BBB63 for hooking me up.
UPDATED: OCT 19, 2004 Deep copper color a slight amount of alcohol is noticeable, but it does not deter from the overall enjoyment of the beer

Bright red color, blazing, as the brewer's description goes, but it could go on to pass for further flavors. Nice, though short, tannish head. Aroma: Oh, my! You want malt, come hither, it's huge, it's sweet, it's here! Toffeeish, caramel-like, so candy-like, that I've got half a mind to drink the thing!
Hugeness everywhere, in malt, mostly, but with plenty of hops, a great helping of sweet, tasty, deliciousness. I scratched my head long and hard, but couldn't think of anything more profound or appropriate. Yum, I say again, and yum is the final verdict. 
Such a wonderful doppelbock, warm in all the best ways, a treat from start to finish. On tap, gorgeous...from a bottle, pretty damn nice.

This is a wonderful beer, malty with caramel sweet overtones, full of seasonal flavor, unusual for a lager.  Beautifully clear with a deep copper color as brilliant as a leaf.  Considerable alcohol warmth but still smooth and deceptively drinkable.  Medium bodied for a big beer.
Am i at the fair eating on a candy apple or am i drinking a beer? It even kinda looks like caramel. Excellent aroma of candy apple too. I liked it.
doughy rich, powerful aroma, very much like amber home brew extract.  Brown and bloody color, carmel, unbalanced, no complexity.
Reddish brown color, frothy head, nicely laced. Malty nose. Well balanced fairly complex malty flavours. Meduim body.
smells exactly like malt extract, reddish brown, nutty caramel maltiness with a soft mouthfeel and zero hop presence
Smells like Munton's malt extract.  Amber/dark orange colour.  Buttery/caramel flavour.  I like.
Thin pink head sits on top of this nice copper color ale. Caramel and apple flavor. Nice.
SLightly malty aroma.  A little more bitterness than I would have expected.  Maltiness carries well throughout.  Finishes somewhat sweet.

clear & copper..thin halo of suds..sweet malty aroma hinting at sugary caramel...solid thick & full body..nutty sweet flavors with hints of caramel candy, nutty creamcycles, and just plain caramelly goodness.
UPDATED: JAN 4, 2004 A dusky red with constant effervescence.  A caramel monster wrapped in apples and plums.  Fun and refreshing.  Many thanks to David P.!
Roasty and malty sweet nose, has a sharp sourness kick in, sweet and sour. Finish is on the dry side.
Beautiful fire red color with a nice tight head. Rich, toasty malt aroma. Caramel, malty, bready flavors. Good balancing bitterness. Thanks captaincougar.

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2004 Dark amber colour, good carbonation very active, medium/small tan frothy head. Good amounts of lacing. Sweet nose, some malts, (hops?) but mostly malts. Lots of sweet malts in the taste, some toffie but the malts is not overpowering. Medium bodied and overall pleasant drink.

UPDATED: FEB 28, 2004 A hazy ruby amber with a thick diminishing tan head. Sweet aroma of banana, toffee, bread and spice.  The 'banana bread' aroma description given by ChimayBabe is very accurate. Medium creamy palate with a decent amount of carbonation.  Sweet flavor filled with malt, toffee, spice, red apple, bananas and dark fruit.  A tiny bit of sourness creeps in at the end, although the sweetness still heavily dominates.  Very good.

The pour a brilliant burnished copper color with the head pythonic in size, creamy in consistency and a beauteous light tan color, as it ever so slowly fades into obscurity a satiny curtain remains to ensconce the glass. The aroma of raisins, maybe even over ripe plums also sweet malt and a slight musky tone noticed, excellent nose to be sure, start is ambrosial, thick with malt and the top middling in feel to the palate. Finish is benign in its acidity, the hops delightful in their spiciness, very dry and lingering aftertaste, one Quaffable Brew Tis True!
Deep ruby red body - wonderful to look at.  Sweet caramel at the front and down the center, followed by chewy toffee and some sourness.  It all blends together with a slight hop bite at the back.

UPDATED: MAR 30, 2004 Deep reddish brown color, thick rocky tan head.  One of the best looking beers I've seen a in a long while.  Healthy carbonation.  This tastes like a marzen with some pretty spicy hops thrown in.  I would like the hops to be a little bit less bitter, as I think they clash a bit with the rich sweetness.  Otherwise an enjoyable brew.
Dark toffee malt & banana bread aroma. Luscious, rich, addictive. Very, veru slight touch of hops for balance. Like a good slice of cake, it is hard to drink this slowly.
Definitely a warmer upper. Fire is a good description for this brew. Tasty, a little spicy and very smooth. I really like this. If its available in your area, I'll bet you like it too.

The deep red body of this brew is topped by a thick off white creamy head with a good amount of lacing left behind.  Slightly sweet yet slightly sour malty aroma with slight fruity notes and a decent hop balance.  Slightly sweet and malty flavor with notes of caramel, a slight fruitiness and a touch of hops.  Medium bodied and smooth with a slight tingle from the carbonation.

vibrant ruby body with a tight, foamy tan head.  nose is caramelty sweet, mildly roasted.  very well balanced, ripe and fruity, full and rich.  some chocolate notes as well.  as rich, full and complex as a dubbel!  velvety smooth , solid beer, warm and rich, damn fine bier!

A Dopplebock! Yum! This one poured a small sized tan head that was fully dissipated. The body was dense with a copper hue. The nose consisted of malt and caramel with a hint of vanilla. The flavor tasted of alcohol, malt and caramel with a tingly and smooth mouthfeel. This beer was medium bodied and there was no lacing.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2003 This Dopplebock was acquired in trade with Bigbadbear63, a fantastic trader! Poured into my Samuel Smiths Nonic glass this beer looks amazing! The body is  mahogany in color nicely complimenting the cream colored head, and leaving behind a substantial lacing. The aroma is malty and sweet, some notes of pit fruits. The flavor is transcendent. The malt is delightful, notes of raisins, plums, and some fig are clear and pronounced, very enchanting. I would think that Autumnal Fire must have a decent ABV, probably 5.5-8.0; in fact a remnant of  alcohol lingers on in the finish, quit lovely. Double-B-63, thanks for another great brew!

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2008 Poured a deep dark amber red with a fairly good head, no lacing.  The aroma is quite malty with not much hoppiness.  Flavor is all around malt with a good dose of carmel and a very slight bitter finish to balance it out.  The palate is good and thick, but not overly so.  Yes, this is good stuff.  Update on 10/17/2003:  I had this tonight with some Maytag Blue Cheese - Oh man, marries perfectly!  It soooooo brings out the sweetness of the Autumnal Fire...  Update on 11/06/2003:  This has become my favorite fall beer by far.  Have some while raking leaves (or running the leaf blower)!  Update 10/3/2008:  Five years on and still loving the Fire.  This is now ritual - leaves turn, air gets crisp, and buy a six of the Fire.  Enjoy...

Thanks to BigBadBear for suggesting I try this one.  This brew pouyred a medium sized head of fine to medium sized mostly lasting light brown colored bubbles that left behind a fair lacing and a hazy brown colored body with no visible carbonation.  The nose is made  up of a rice caramel malt with an essence of hop to it.  The mouthfeel starts off smoothm, tingles in the middle and finishes with a mild alcohol hop bite.  The alcohol mouthfeel increases as it warms and begins to burn slightly as it goes down.  The flavor is a very tasty vinuous caramel malt hop one with its alcohol content overpowering the other flavors.  Was that a hint of maple in the background?  I copped a decent buzz of of one bottle.  I wonder what the ABV of this brew is.  I would guess around 8-10%.  It definately has some kick to it.

Amazing color, brightly deep, ruby reddish fire color with a hint of brownish tone darkening it up a bit more. Maybe thats where they came up with the name 'Autumnal Fire'. Vigorous pour produced a hefty dark ivory, smoothened head with some bigger bubbles and little divets, slowly draining down to a fine skim always present and some sticky thick stringed lace and spots.
Aroma is that of most Capital brews, a familiar malty sweetness with some notes of thick starfuit and very dulled dark citrusy-like plums and melons, roastyness is light and very subdued and lends some caramel. 
Taste is also very much like other Capital brews, with the familiar malty sweetness, reminds me of the Maibock and Blonde Dopplebock, sweetness is incredibly smooth and buttery with good amounts of caramel malts, furnishing some toffee and very dulled fruits; starfruit, light plum, over ripe melon, and fig. Not all that complex, but loaded full of malts, just as a good dopple should be, as this is. Lightly chewy and sticky, but smooth over all, medium body feel with a lingering sweetness in the finish. Very enjoyable, quite smooth, and just all around pleasingly yummy and good.

Dark hazy copper hue with a small frothy off-white head and good lacing. Big heavy roasted malt aroma with nutty and caramel characteristics. Nose also hinted of light floral hops, raisin, brown sugar, and vanilla. Some phenol notes as well. Initial taste was sticky and sweet. Minor hop presence shows up later. Moderately alcoholic feel and lightly acidic finish. Medium to full-bodied with an oily and lush mouthfeel. Very good German bock style bier. Very inviting and good for those crisp autumn nights. Recommended.

UPDATED: APR 5, 2004 Glad to get my hands on a VERY fresh batch of this seasonal... Pours with a jewel-red color, the aroma of Munich at harvest meets the nose immediately, or so I have imagined Munich at harvest to smell.  Flavors are of expertly handled German malts, truely a "Double Oktoberfest".  Sweetness is prominent, but not cloying.  A beautiful lager worth seeking out.
